Carl Sagan was an absolute GENIUS

Carl Sagan's enthusiasm and passion for astronomy made Cosmos a pleasure to read. Sagan is a master at explaining astronomical concepts in layman's terms. But this book touches on not just cosmology, but also goes into the history of scientific thought and introduces the reader to some of the most influential scientists/philosophers who have contributed to man's understanding of the universe over the last 2500 years. His book also weaves in evolutionary concepts, chemistry and physics. Because Cosmos was written in the 1980's, some parts of the book are dated, but I really don't think this takes away from the overall story. It is well worth a read for someone interested in cosmology.

I quite liked this book. Apart from Sagan’s ridicule of astrology and all things spiritual and God’ish, that is. That seemed quite counterintuitive and counterproductive, as well as close minded and prejudiced, after claiming his aim is to understand, and after he himself points out, that research needs to stay humble and open minded and to not fall into the trap of thinking it knows best.... [eyeroll]If we are made of the atoms of the universe, if there is gravity pulling planets and whole star systems and galaxies around, why not even entertain and investigate the astrological notions of humans being affected by astrological events?Because that is what’s at the base of astrology as a science, which isn’t very comparable to do with a few apparent ‘astrology’ lines in a weekly magazine. That’s like reducing math to a few basic calculations that you can do with your 10 fingers, and then ridiculing it as childish, claiming it not to be a science.Or claiming that art doesn’t exist or isn’t real, just because every child can draw, or hit a few piano keys, but not every child turns out to be an artist or a musical genius. If you claim to be a scientist, then please, at least study the complex math, astronomy and psychology behind real astrology, before you rule it out. You might want to reconsider your prejudices once you get to know the science behind it.....The same goes for spiritual notions and claims of extraterrestrial visits and messages like cropcircles that is either not even considered in the book or taken a firm stand against. Look a little deeper into it, and you will see that a lot of the explanations, views, causalities are actually both interesting and probable, and fit with many of the scienctific principles and finds that is described in this book, and so deserve a lot more attention from science than scorn. What about time- and placetravel possibilities? And maybe, just maybe, extraterrestrials ciukd have technology that they don’t have to obey the same ‘slow’ laws that we abide by? What about at least just CONSIDERING these possibilities?Maybe there is information and keys to apparent mysteries right under your noses, that the ‘scientists’ are just too arrogant to consider, and therefore they will miss out. Untill the next non-dogmatic, fearless, open minded, curious, thinker comes along and makes discoveries and deductions, and experiements, and finds new proof and open up the whole field again...Here is a possible hypotheses, that would actually help explain some of the plot holes and mysteries in the evolutionary theory that claims that EVERYTHING happens by chance [cue; eyeroll]. The hypothesis goes that extraterrestrials helped ‘seed’ the planet, and potentially has been involved throughout at certain points, watching or interacting, like scientist, and we are the experimental objects. So maybe they experimented on Earth, on us, and that helped evolution along. So then it would not ALL just be plain coincidence, some of course, as a scientist controls certain factors and let others unfold to see what happens, but there would be an intelligence at play. Adding an intelligence factor that can observe, adjust, and manipulate with the objects and the process, would explain a lot of the ‘gaps’ that evolution theories and biologist can’t fill out or wrap their minds around. Sagan actually comes very close to this idea, as he does wonder if maybe alien forces ARE already here, invisibly watching us. But then how come he hasn’t even considered the idea or made the leap that they might have been here on/off throughout the millennia, helping evolution along? And that maybe back then they interacted with us? And maybe many of the old religions and descriptions of Gods is just that; humans interacting with more advanced extraterrestrials, or Gods, as they might have perceived them to be? Worth considering and investigating if you are a true scientist, claiming to wanting to know, and not being blinded by your prejudices or what you claim to know as the Truth, I’d say.Also; a real and good scientist should be careful of their own bias and prejudice as it closes down their mind to possibilities. I liked the ties to biological, historical and sociological and psychological areas the most, as those are my main field of interests, and overall I felt enriched by reading this book and by the knowledge it presented. I only wish Sagan and other scientists would use their voice and knowledge even more to speak for Earth and humans though, and how we are headed for self-destruction if we don’t change our ways and values.

My earliest recollections of this book are a mix of the blurred stars of the book jacket, the original airing of the PBS series, and its connection to my father. Considering I was only 3 years old at the time, this strikes me as an indication of its import. What I remember distinctly are sitting beside the couch and watching with my father as a long DNA strand stretched out across the television screen and images of the hardbound book in my father's personal library.A few years after the first run of this series on PBS, my father died. Cosmos always held a certain fascination for me, as a book, as I identified it with my father, but I never read it. Not until a few years ago. Perhaps just to see what my father saw, or to learn what brought the book and series such reverence.Oh, and what a world.Inspirational, life affirming, and filled with starry-eyed wonder, Sagan's magnum opus pleads the case for science as the preferred lens through which to see the world. Written in a time when humanity seemed to teeter on the brink of mutually assured destruction, Sagan argued for rational behavior, for the unity of humanity and absurdity of petty power struggles, for the scientific method as a way to interpret events around us rather than prominent pseudosciences (e.g., astrology) with tenets that seemed deliberately vague and arbitrary (and surprisingly easy to debunk, given their popularity), how we benefit from being skeptical, and the great potential of the human race.This book earns my unadulterated praise for building upon a philosophy that human beings can do well for themselves if they'd bother considering their ridiculous behaviors and learn how to act sensibly. The potential is there, as evinced by the leaps made by individuals throughout human history. Whether or not we choose to stand upon the shoulders of giants, or cower in their shadows, remains to be seen.I like to believe that this was a philosophy my father shared and would have taught me firsthand if he'd been around. It's a philosophy I feel I adopted anyway, and, as a result of this similarity, I want to believe in some way a bit of him is preserved in me.But don't just read the book. To get the full experience, watch the PBS series released in 1980, narrated by Sagan himself and scored by Vangelis (later known for 
Chariots of Fire
, 
The Last of the Mohicans
,and 
Blade Runner
, to name a few, but his breakthrough, and one of his best works, remains one of the themes to the 1970 French documentary on the animal kingdom, L'Apocalypse des animaux, la petite fille de la mer).There's a reason Cosmos is the most widely viewed PBS Series in the world. Beautifully stated and brilliantly scored, it tells the story of humanity, our universe, and how we fit within it.On a personal level, it is a bridge back to my father, an inspiring philosophy, a source of wonder regarding how our world might evolve if the portions of ourselves that influence what is best in us are lost, and whether or not we can avoid disaster long enough to fully realize our potential in spite of ourselves.If you can't read the book, or watch the series, do yourself a favor and, at the very least, watch this.ADDENDUM:It has come to my attention that an updated version of this landmark series will be hosted in 2014 by none other than Neil deGrasse Tyson, entitled COSMOS: A SpaceTime Odyssey. The trailer shows the new version is very true to the original, with Sagan's infamous Cosmic Calendar, the spaceship of the mind, Johannes Kepler, and several other memorable moments from the 1980s series.

Apart from some flaws & misconceptions, i like the way, Carl described everything.Cosmos is a comprehensive book dealing with history of astronomy and evolution. It tells how matter transformed and how civilizations grew up together.

When you spot a rainbow, you point it out to people who might not be looking. When you see a shooting star flash across the sky but your friends miss it, you wish they could have seen it as well. It is in our nature to share the wonder of extraordinary experiences with others. We do it instinctively. Perhaps, we want so desperately for others to look because we know, subconsciously, that there is no way we could describe the hues of that rainbow or the awe inspired by that shooting star in our own words. I feel something similar about this book and I hope that you will read it for yourself. This book is a history of science and the culmination of one man's lifelong wonder for it. It is a paean to the fact that we are not the center of the universe, as individuals or species, and how that is in fact a beautiful thing. If nothing else, you will cherish that one lesson for long after you read this. I know I will.

This was absolutely amazing, and I can't believe it took me so long to get around to reading it. If you read only one book in your lifetime, this should be that book. It covers everything: the origins of the Universe, the creation of chemical elements, formation of planets, evolution of life, the slow process humankind has gone through to discover the world and Universe, why it has taken so long to relearn what was lost in the Dark Ages, the harmful effects of religion, the reason for so many Creation myths, the possibility of other life in the Universe, the danger of nuclear war (happily, this discussion felt quite dated), and why space exploration is important.I consider myself fortunate to have seen Mr Sagan speak, on the danger of nuclear proliferation. He was a fantastic speaker; I should have known then that his books would be equally (if not more!) fantastic.

“Cosmos is a Greek word for the order of the universe. It is, in a way, the opposite of Chaos. It implies the deep interconnectedness of all things. It conveys awe for the intricate and subtle way in which the universe is put together.” “The Cosmos is all that is or was or ever will be. Our feeblest contemplations of the Cosmos stir us -- there is a tingling in the spine, a catch in the voice, a faint sensation, as if a distant memory, of falling from a height. We know we are approaching the greatest of mysteries.”

This would have been a great book at the time of its publication, but in 2019 it is a book about astronomy that was written a decade before the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. In other words, it is quite outdated. Sagan is a talented writer, but I found myself tiring of his overawed tone by the later chapters. As work became significantly busier about halfway through reading this, I ended up leaving it to sit for over two weeks with just 78 pages left to read. Realistically, if I had been enjoying it more I would have found the time to finish it. If nothing else it provided a lesson in why one should not choose a book by fame alone.2/5 stars

Absolutely stunning book. I only heard less about Carl Sagan before I read this book, but now I can understand why he is among the best respected scholars of all time. Sagan, in depth knowledge and passion in every area of sciences cannot go without amusing anyone. Books not only about genesis of universe but speaks very well about origins of life and evolution, hence you feel more like complete handbook of science when you read it. I got glued to the book throughout, it is just fascinating as it is!A Must Read, never to be missed!

Brilliant as show is.Sagan's prose is magical, a journey from Big Bang to evolution of stars, planets, solar systems, life on earth,possibility of extraterristrial life to history of Homo sapiens to Moons of Mars,Saturn etc.,an enthralling voyage.

This would serve as a good, albeit somewhat dated, introduction to astronomy, astrophysics and cosmology. It was written with reference to the popular 13-part television series hosted by author Sagan and would be most profitably read subsequent to a viewing. It was inspiring, coaxing young minds to go out and look at the sky and imagine. Astronomy still interests me to date and the book is definitely a favorite.

This is largely a book of pantheistic scripture posturing as a science textbook. The science parts are interesting; Sagan's materialistic cosmos worship seems to be a fundamental source for milennial secular humanistic belief and practice; the history is shallow, poorly understood, and anachronistic.

I know it's heresy to not love Carl Sagan's Cosmos... I just really didn't. It was heralded as being so amazing, so powerful, so accessible to laymen. I found it dull. There is so much cool stuff in the universe, but this just felt like a textbook.

I was bonkers for astronomy and planetary science in about 8th grade, when the original series ran on TV. I can still get completely absorbed by the latest news and discoveries about space. I don't believe in heaven, but I really wish and hope Carl got the grand tour.
What an inspirational read this is! It made me keen to study, igniting a passion for reading and learning.

Cosmos is a joyous romp through space and time; genuine wonder at the beauty of galaxies, the music of spheres, the mountain of history it took to get us to the knowledge we possess about the universe today. It is not so much a science book as it is a book about everything, giving us much-needed context on the scale of things — how vast a universe measured in light years, how temporary a human lifespan, how microscopic the building blocks of matter — and how splendous the whole concoction: tiny electrical forces of push and pull holding together entire galaxies, and creating beings capable of marvelling at it all.I especially enjoyed the chapters bringing me to Venus, Mars, and Jupiter, and allowing me to bear witness to the birth and death of stars. Venus: a hellish place with 480°C surface temperature and 90 atmospheres of surface pressure, and an eternal rain of sulphuric acid in the atmosphere which never reaches the surface due to the high temperature. Mars: open bodies of water are impossible because the pressure is too low to keep it from boiling. Jupiter: a failed star radiating light in the infrared spectrum, big enough to contain a thousand Earths. And stars: their gravity brings particles close together for nuclear forces to overcome the natural repulsion between protons and electrons, fusing hydrogen particles together to form helium and giving off gamma photons in the process. When all the hydrogen is fused, the mass of the star determines its eventual fate into black dwarf, neutron star, or black hole. Along the way, the methods that astronomy has developed, like astronomical spectroscopy, to deduce these faraway conditions, and the expeditions — including the failures — to these planets for verification.Of noteworthy mention is Sagan’s inclusion of the process of arriving at our present conclusions, as he briefly presents a history of mistaken beliefs continuously corrected by scientific inquiry. What this serves to reinforce is the idea that what we know about the world is subject to change — but this is beautiful because we, coming later on the timeline of human civilisation, can still contribute to this giant repository of knowledge.Science is not just a pure pursuit of knowledge; it is very much affected by prevailing systems of power and beliefs. Sagan synthesizes thousands of years of (mostly Western) civilised history to present an argument for the causes of the acceleration and deceleration of the rate of scientific discovery. A great scientific boom occurred around the 5th to 6th century BC in Ionia, with the seeds of thought for a world formed not by Gods but by natural processes, the establishment of medical tradition (Hippocrates), the conception of the atom (Greek for unable to be cut), and many more, because, Sagan believes, it was comprised of a group of islands with no single concentration of power to enforce social and intellectual conformity. Diversity is the key ingredient to progress, providing a healthy cross fertilisation of ideas. Yet its reliance on the slave economy led to a lack of impetus for advancing technology, as well as an increased disdain towards manual labour, which was placed in opposition to spiritual pursuits, associated with the so-called elites. Ironically, Pythagoras and his followers, with their belief in pure theory unsullied by the world, contributed to the demise of progress, and would later influence a Christianity that suppressed free thought in order to maintain its hold on power.I found the last couple of chapters — arguments for the possibility of life elsewhere, and a warning against self-destruction through war — less satisfying than the rest of the book, as it wades into social science territory that comes off less as condensed material than as simplistic models. I raised my eyebrows at Sagan’s summary of a James W. Prescott’s findings — cultures lavishing physical affection on infants and allowing expression of sexual activity in adolescents are disinclined to violence — which Sagan proffers as the solution to world peace. While well-intentioned, it does not stand up in the strength of its argument to the rest of the book, and would perhaps have been better left as a couple of concluding paragraphs painting our possible paths: humanity annihilated through nuclear wars, versus the continued potential for awe at the worlds left for us to discover.This is a book in love with the universe; you will come off it with a renewed sense of wonder, and a growing curiosity for all things space and quantum.4.5/5

I have read this book after having watched the (amazing!) thirteen parts documentary, so, to be honest, here's just a template to the show. In fact, I couldn't but hear Sagan's voice and picture images from the show while reading; a great testimony to how striking and enthralling 'Cosmos' is! Having said that, who doesn't like Carl Sagan? On paper or live, he truly owns it! There is something akin to childish wonders with him, and he never fails to take you in amazing journey. Certainly dense but once you get into a passage it’s enthralling. Some concepts were raised in ways that made me put the book down and reconsider what I’d read. Quotes:“The secrets of evolution are death and time.”“What a marvelous cooperation arrangement—plants and animals each inhaling the other’s exhalations, a kind of planet-wide mutual mouth-to-stoma resuscitation, the entire elegant cycle powered by a star 150 million kilometers away.”“But if the Cosmos is closed and light cannot escape from it, then it may be perfectly correct to deceive the universe as a black hole. If you wish to know what it is like inside a black hole, look around you.”It’s also insane how stacked the 6th century BC was: “Thales, Anaximander, and Pythagoras in Ionia, Pharaoh Necho in Egypt, Zoroaster in Persia, Confucius and Lao-Tse in China, Jewish prophets in Israel, Egypt and Babylonia, and Guatama Buddha in India”.

The span of subjects in Carl Sagan's Cosmos is wide, from the history of science to (almost) modern cosmology, from the theory of evolution to interstellar flights, from creating gods to knowing our own home - Solar System. One thing you should keep in mind: I would not recommend this book to anyone with only very basic knowledge in physics. Cosmos was first published in 1980, and science has developed enormously since. There are new theories about space that correct or completely reject some of the assumptions in this book. And for those with deeper knowledge in physics there's not much to learn, but personally for me it was interesting to see what cosmology was like in 70-80s.For example, when it comes to The Big Bang and black holes I take the side of the theory of singularities. There's nothing about singularities in Cosmos. We just have to accept that we didn't know much about black holes back in 1980. That they're not completely black, that they radiate? Also, I'm not sure I'm comfortable with the suggested theory that our expanding Universe can be viewed as a black hole. Nope. There were other small disagreements I had during reading but that didn't make my experience any less exciting.As for the writing, Cosmos is accessible for anyone. There's no going into equations, diagrams or whatsoever.Coming to my favourite part of the book, it has to be chapters devoted to extraterrestrial life and search for it. I just can't help it.And, if you ignore generalized or incorrect theories in the book, there are a lot of philosophical questions raised to ponder about.

Quite simply—and obviously—the best popular science book ever written. Using beautiful prose, solid reasoning, historical context, philosophical power, and lavish illustrations, Sagan does an unsurpassed job conveying the mystery of the cosmos to the average reader. To be sure, some of the material is dated or has been superseded by later research, but as a snapshot of the understanding as of 1980 it is excellent. Even better, for those up-to-date with current theories and observational data, the book offers a fun way to see for yourself how science evolves itself toward better understanding, unlike some other more rigid value systems. In fact, I first read this book thirty years ago, and re-read it recently to compare with the upcoming 2014 TV series "Cosmos: A Space-Time Odyssey" by astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson, billed as an update to Sagan's original series.Don't be afraid to read Sagan's book, all that's required is an open mind.

While the PBS series is dated now in its special effects, the ability of Sagan to inspire the wonderment of science and our connection with the universe is unparalleled to this day. I recommend the hardback edition, which has excellent photographs and other images. I read somewhere that Cosmos has sold more books in foreign languages than any book other than the Bible. I hope this is true. It is a book that everyone should read, and if you can watch the series, do so! (just accept the goofy effects as being a product of their age). Maybe if we all realize that we are starstuff, we would work together to save ourselves and our planet, rather than continuing on our consumeristic, capitalistic path of self destruction. Carl is king!

Given that this book was published in 1980, it is naturally a bit dated. Sagan only dreams of rovers on Mars and rendezvous with comets, and is much concerned with the arms race between US and USSR. But the fundamentals of astrophysics and rich history of early space exploration are still very much the way they would be described in a modern popular science book. It captures imagination and gets you excited about the universe all over again. There certainly is value in reading classic science books today, even though we might have progressed significantly since then.

If you ever become curious understanding things, this should be the first book to read!

Carl Sagan was an absolute GENIUS

Carl Sagan's enthusiasm and passion for astronomy made Cosmos a pleasure to read. Sagan is a master at explaining astronomical concepts in layman's terms. But this book touches on not just cosmology, but also goes into the history of scientific thought and introduces the reader to some of the most influential scientists/philosophers who have contributed to man's understanding of the universe over the last 2500 years. His book also weaves in evolutionary concepts, chemistry and physics. Because Cosmos was written in the 1980's, some parts of the book are dated, but I really don't think this takes away from the overall story. It is well worth a read for someone interested in cosmology.

I quite liked this book. Apart from Sagan’s ridicule of astrology and all things spiritual and God’ish, that is. That seemed quite counterintuitive and counterproductive, as well as close minded and prejudiced, after claiming his aim is to understand, and after he himself points out, that research needs to stay humble and open minded and to not fall into the trap of thinking it knows best.... [eyeroll]If we are made of the atoms of the universe, if there is gravity pulling planets and whole star systems and galaxies around, why not even entertain and investigate the astrological notions of humans being affected by astrological events?Because that is what’s at the base of astrology as a science, which isn’t very comparable to do with a few apparent ‘astrology’ lines in a weekly magazine. That’s like reducing math to a few basic calculations that you can do with your 10 fingers, and then ridiculing it as childish, claiming it not to be a science.Or claiming that art doesn’t exist or isn’t real, just because every child can draw, or hit a few piano keys, but not every child turns out to be an artist or a musical genius. If you claim to be a scientist, then please, at least study the complex math, astronomy and psychology behind real astrology, before you rule it out. You might want to reconsider your prejudices once you get to know the science behind it.....The same goes for spiritual notions and claims of extraterrestrial visits and messages like cropcircles that is either not even considered in the book or taken a firm stand against. Look a little deeper into it, and you will see that a lot of the explanations, views, causalities are actually both interesting and probable, and fit with many of the scienctific principles and finds that is described in this book, and so deserve a lot more attention from science than scorn. What about time- and placetravel possibilities? And maybe, just maybe, extraterrestrials ciukd have technology that they don’t have to obey the same ‘slow’ laws that we abide by? What about at least just CONSIDERING these possibilities?Maybe there is information and keys to apparent mysteries right under your noses, that the ‘scientists’ are just too arrogant to consider, and therefore they will miss out. Untill the next non-dogmatic, fearless, open minded, curious, thinker comes along and makes discoveries and deductions, and experiements, and finds new proof and open up the whole field again...Here is a possible hypotheses, that would actually help explain some of the plot holes and mysteries in the evolutionary theory that claims that EVERYTHING happens by chance [cue; eyeroll]. The hypothesis goes that extraterrestrials helped ‘seed’ the planet, and potentially has been involved throughout at certain points, watching or interacting, like scientist, and we are the experimental objects. So maybe they experimented on Earth, on us, and that helped evolution along. So then it would not ALL just be plain coincidence, some of course, as a scientist controls certain factors and let others unfold to see what happens, but there would be an intelligence at play. Adding an intelligence factor that can observe, adjust, and manipulate with the objects and the process, would explain a lot of the ‘gaps’ that evolution theories and biologist can’t fill out or wrap their minds around. Sagan actually comes very close to this idea, as he does wonder if maybe alien forces ARE already here, invisibly watching us. But then how come he hasn’t even considered the idea or made the leap that they might have been here on/off throughout the millennia, helping evolution along? And that maybe back then they interacted with us? And maybe many of the old religions and descriptions of Gods is just that; humans interacting with more advanced extraterrestrials, or Gods, as they might have perceived them to be? Worth considering and investigating if you are a true scientist, claiming to wanting to know, and not being blinded by your prejudices or what you claim to know as the Truth, I’d say.Also; a real and good scientist should be careful of their own bias and prejudice as it closes down their mind to possibilities. I liked the ties to biological, historical and sociological and psychological areas the most, as those are my main field of interests, and overall I felt enriched by reading this book and by the knowledge it presented. I only wish Sagan and other scientists would use their voice and knowledge even more to speak for Earth and humans though, and how we are headed for self-destruction if we don’t change our ways and values.

My earliest recollections of this book are a mix of the blurred stars of the book jacket, the original airing of the PBS series, and its connection to my father. Considering I was only 3 years old at the time, this strikes me as an indication of its import. What I remember distinctly are sitting beside the couch and watching with my father as a long DNA strand stretched out across the television screen and images of the hardbound book in my father's personal library.A few years after the first run of this series on PBS, my father died. Cosmos always held a certain fascination for me, as a book, as I identified it with my father, but I never read it. Not until a few years ago. Perhaps just to see what my father saw, or to learn what brought the book and series such reverence.Oh, and what a world.Inspirational, life affirming, and filled with starry-eyed wonder, Sagan's magnum opus pleads the case for science as the preferred lens through which to see the world. Written in a time when humanity seemed to teeter on the brink of mutually assured destruction, Sagan argued for rational behavior, for the unity of humanity and absurdity of petty power struggles, for the scientific method as a way to interpret events around us rather than prominent pseudosciences (e.g., astrology) with tenets that seemed deliberately vague and arbitrary (and surprisingly easy to debunk, given their popularity), how we benefit from being skeptical, and the great potential of the human race.This book earns my unadulterated praise for building upon a philosophy that human beings can do well for themselves if they'd bother considering their ridiculous behaviors and learn how to act sensibly. The potential is there, as evinced by the leaps made by individuals throughout human history. Whether or not we choose to stand upon the shoulders of giants, or cower in their shadows, remains to be seen.I like to believe that this was a philosophy my father shared and would have taught me firsthand if he'd been around. It's a philosophy I feel I adopted anyway, and, as a result of this similarity, I want to believe in some way a bit of him is preserved in me.But don't just read the book. To get the full experience, watch the PBS series released in 1980, narrated by Sagan himself and scored by Vangelis (later known for 
Chariots of Fire
, 
The Last of the Mohicans
,and 
Blade Runner
, to name a few, but his breakthrough, and one of his best works, remains one of the themes to the 1970 French documentary on the animal kingdom, L'Apocalypse des animaux, la petite fille de la mer).There's a reason Cosmos is the most widely viewed PBS Series in the world. Beautifully stated and brilliantly scored, it tells the story of humanity, our universe, and how we fit within it.On a personal level, it is a bridge back to my father, an inspiring philosophy, a source of wonder regarding how our world might evolve if the portions of ourselves that influence what is best in us are lost, and whether or not we can avoid disaster long enough to fully realize our potential in spite of ourselves.If you can't read the book, or watch the series, do yourself a favor and, at the very least, watch this.ADDENDUM:It has come to my attention that an updated version of this landmark series will be hosted in 2014 by none other than Neil deGrasse Tyson, entitled COSMOS: A SpaceTime Odyssey. The trailer shows the new version is very true to the original, with Sagan's infamous Cosmic Calendar, the spaceship of the mind, Johannes Kepler, and several other memorable moments from the 1980s series.

Apart from some flaws & misconceptions, i like the way, Carl described everything.Cosmos is a comprehensive book dealing with history of astronomy and evolution. It tells how matter transformed and how civilizations grew up together.

When you spot a rainbow, you point it out to people who might not be looking. When you see a shooting star flash across the sky but your friends miss it, you wish they could have seen it as well. It is in our nature to share the wonder of extraordinary experiences with others. We do it instinctively. Perhaps, we want so desperately for others to look because we know, subconsciously, that there is no way we could describe the hues of that rainbow or the awe inspired by that shooting star in our own words. I feel something similar about this book and I hope that you will read it for yourself. This book is a history of science and the culmination of one man's lifelong wonder for it. It is a paean to the fact that we are not the center of the universe, as individuals or species, and how that is in fact a beautiful thing. If nothing else, you will cherish that one lesson for long after you read this. I know I will.

This was absolutely amazing, and I can't believe it took me so long to get around to reading it. If you read only one book in your lifetime, this should be that book. It covers everything: the origins of the Universe, the creation of chemical elements, formation of planets, evolution of life, the slow process humankind has gone through to discover the world and Universe, why it has taken so long to relearn what was lost in the Dark Ages, the harmful effects of religion, the reason for so many Creation myths, the possibility of other life in the Universe, the danger of nuclear war (happily, this discussion felt quite dated), and why space exploration is important.I consider myself fortunate to have seen Mr Sagan speak, on the danger of nuclear proliferation. He was a fantastic speaker; I should have known then that his books would be equally (if not more!) fantastic.

“Cosmos is a Greek word for the order of the universe. It is, in a way, the opposite of Chaos. It implies the deep interconnectedness of all things. It conveys awe for the intricate and subtle way in which the universe is put together.” “The Cosmos is all that is or was or ever will be. Our feeblest contemplations of the Cosmos stir us -- there is a tingling in the spine, a catch in the voice, a faint sensation, as if a distant memory, of falling from a height. We know we are approaching the greatest of mysteries.”

This would have been a great book at the time of its publication, but in 2019 it is a book about astronomy that was written a decade before the launch of the Hubble Space Telescope. In other words, it is quite outdated. Sagan is a talented writer, but I found myself tiring of his overawed tone by the later chapters. As work became significantly busier about halfway through reading this, I ended up leaving it to sit for over two weeks with just 78 pages left to read. Realistically, if I had been enjoying it more I would have found the time to finish it. If nothing else it provided a lesson in why one should not choose a book by fame alone.2/5 stars

Absolutely stunning book. I only heard less about Carl Sagan before I read this book, but now I can understand why he is among the best respected scholars of all time. Sagan, in depth knowledge and passion in every area of sciences cannot go without amusing anyone. Books not only about genesis of universe but speaks very well about origins of life and evolution, hence you feel more like complete handbook of science when you read it. I got glued to the book throughout, it is just fascinating as it is!A Must Read, never to be missed!

Brilliant as show is.Sagan's prose is magical, a journey from Big Bang to evolution of stars, planets, solar systems, life on earth,possibility of extraterristrial life to history of Homo sapiens to Moons of Mars,Saturn etc.,an enthralling voyage.

I've listened to about a third of this and am giving it up. This isn't a criticism of the book or of the narration, both of which are excellent. Sagan's book was undoubtedly ground-breaking and later popular science books owe much to his legacy, but I feel if I was recommending a comprehensive pop science book about life, the universe and everything, it would make sense to recommend a new one, rather than one that, however well done at the time, undoubtedly now contains some stuff that has been superceded by later discoveries. In this monumental tour de force, the late Carl Sagan pays a stupendous tribute to Science, the vast Phalanx of Stars adorning a plethora of Galaxies and to the serendipitous findings that are the efforts of a few stellar men and women who strove to understand Evolution, Cosmos and the very meaning of life.In this gripping achievement of common sense, thought and reason,this beloved and genial astronomer does his best to make us understand our purpose on this Planet. Exquisitely tracing our path of evolution that involved, in what may seem to be an absurd improbability, a Devonian fish, to the act of firing a couple of Interstellar Spaceships (Voyagers I & II) into the depths of outer space, Carl Sagan eloquently, elegantly and enthusiastically holds forth on the Cosmological significance that is essential to appreciate our existence on Planet Earth. Although an encomium to Science, there runs throughout the book an invisible, but strong thread of spirituality and deep philosophy. Every page strives and, and succeeds in no small measure in underscoring the significantly infinitesimal position that mankind occupies in the Cosmic Playground. But completely ignorant of such a tiny confinement in the theatre of Space, man chooses to continually envelope himself in a self created blanket of vice and vicissitude. How vainglorious and trivial are the self proclaimed triumphs of the Homo Sapien when compared to the stirring functionalities of the Cosmos!Although some of the concepts such as black holes, quarks and supernovae pose a veritable challenge to even able quantum physicists, let alone an unsuspecting layman, Sagan takes care to handhold the reader through the noxious admixture of gases and vapours and deftly evades the path of careening comets and interstellar boulders. Sagan is not just an unflinching servant of Science, but an admirable teacher of the subject that is pinned to his heart. 'Cosmos' will stand the sternest test of anytime. But more than anything else it will serve as a beautiful and timely reminder to we earthlings to re-examine our foibles and follies and channel our tangible resources and intangible potentials towards the causes of empowerment, education and enlightenment instead of getting enmeshed, entangled and embroiled in the temporary passions of Power, Politics and Perniciousness. "COSMOS" - A HUMBLING BUT FULFILLING JOURNEY!

Full disclosure here, Carl Sagan is a personal inspiration for me. A person who has affected my philosophy and thinking ever since I first heard of him, watch his television documentaries, and then took the time to read his writing. The day he died, I felt a huge sense of loss, not for myself, but the world. This man was not only brilliant, a genius of the order that you see only once a generation, but he had the soul and sensitivity that defines the best of humanity. Overstating? I don't think so; he not only had the mental capacity to see the world differently, but he always--in his writing, science, achievements and activities--seemed to think FIRST, how any phenomena would impact the entire human race. And his conclusions, scientific or otherwise, always led him to the same course of action: A call for understanding, mutual respect and simple caring for one another. This is why he impacted me, and in many ways I carry on his mission.About this book: it captures the infectious wonderment of Sagan's mind and curiosity. His discussions about astronomy not only makes the science easy to grasp, it RIGHTFULLY puts the reader in absolute awe at the vastness and genius of how the universe is put together. This book, which is an encapsulation of the TV series of the same name--which incidentally helped spread science to more people around the world than any piece of scientific literature in history--teaches and informs, but inspires as well. Carl Sagan believed that knowledge, pure knowledge of how things work, is a magical bridge that will erase the differences that divide people, and build mutual understanding through awareness of our common humanity. This he believed will eventually over time, bring the world together, and keep us from destroying ourselves. Cosmos was a contribution to this dream by one of the greatest thinkers of our time; in history really. Sagan always saw the big picture, and by helping us see the same, he figured we could rise above the petty things that destroy us (like ignorance, fear and hatred). I'm sure if he were alive to write this review he would say: it won't solve all your problems or answer all your questions, but hopefully it can give you even one iota of knowledge and understanding, that will lift up your life and help you enrich the lives of those around you as well.

Probably the best book I have ever read; and a book that everyone should read.Life receives a different meaning when we understand its origins and when we realize how small yet lucky we are to have been the result of a fortunate mix of atoms. One of my favorite parts is the search of meaning in wars between nations and...people. All this struggle looks so insignificant given the other possibilities on which we could employ our intelligence and feelings; and given the perishing future and our short lives.“Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another.”“Books break the shackles of time, proof that humans can work magic.”“We are star stuff which has taken its destiny into its own hands.”

In Cosmos, Carl Sagan, through accessible, elegantly romantic prose, takes us on a journey to the stars and imparts on us a very important lesson: that science and mathematics are just as beautiful as the arts. This book is an essential read for anyone who wishes to appreciate the world we live in. People don’t generally associate science with poetry, but the healthy dose of romanticism in Cosmos makes the connection undeniable. Paired with empirical knowledge, concise explanations, and vision, it is undoubtedly one of the best scientific works of the generation. And Sagan, with his vast experience and understanding of the cosmos, his enthusiasm regarding it, and, most importantly, his humble acceptance of the fact that we, as humans, are nothing more than a blip on the cosmic radar - is the perfect narrator for this work. He takes vastly complicated concepts and simplifies them, enough so that anyone, even the epitome of the layman (myself) can understand, learn about, and wonder at the universe right alongside the professionals. This review doesn’t do Cosmos any justice. Please read this book. It is not often that one as amazing as this one comes along. It touched upon so many subjects that I feel as though, after finishing it, I have briefly glimpsed a snapshot of the world; it’s science, history, politics, and philosophy - all in the space of 384 pages.

I love this book. I bought it again (what universe do books you once owned get off to?) to remind myself of Sagan's brain and how he thought about the cosmos. I remember from the first time I read the book that Sagan was one of the few to consider "life as we know it" an egotistical concept about nature on other planets, in other galaxies. And to a girl scifi nerd, this was an important caveat. Of course, there was no 3rd grade on Mars! Of course there weren't boy bullies, and music lessons, and teachers who needed to be doing something else for a living. Perhaps a planet with silica beings, or gas giants who floated in the methane winds of Jupiter. Maybe salt plain beings: maybe Lot's wife was zapped in a fly-by incident? Or an amoeba immersed in a boiling pool of compounds on Venus, contemplating how lucky and alone it is. Or molten rock DNA strands on Mercury, slithering through the cracks in the crust. Why is our armature calcium on an aluminum-rich planet? What would a girl look like on Neptune? Are there girls on Neptune? I love this book. It's a great gift for every dreaming youngster who shows signs of waiting for their mother ship to take them home.

It all started with Neil deGrasse Tyson's " Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey". So, next time when I visited the bookshop Cosmos was the obvious choice. Ah, what a beautiful book starting with such beautiful dedication. Carl is a person with such incredible personality, the more you read him, the more you will want to listen to him. So, next in line was his "Cosmos: A Personal Voyage". While reading the book I felt that the episodes of the series are complementary to the corresponding chapters of the book. So even after completing 70% of the book, I started it all again, this time side by side with corresponding episode from the series. So, this time the experience was more fulfilling, more complete. The satisfaction was at its best.The best part of this classic and the series are that they don't try to introduce science as something distant. Rather they bring things closer, like something at your next door. And this way you feel more connected to the whole picture. Cosmos, the book, the series and overall itself will make you awe with wonder. All of them are such great, wonderful creations that you cannot but adore them.

Cosmos, both this book as well as the companion TV series, contain some of the most moving and poetic descriptions of our universe and the scientific approaches that have helped us understand it. Often in grade school and secondary school, we learn a great deal about the "how" of science, but what can get lost in the sprint toward passing standardized tests is the pure wonder that you feel when you look at a star in the sky and you understand that the light you're seeing actually left that star hundreds or even thousands of years ago.Carl Sagan makes science beautiful and exciting. Sagan takes you on a journey that leaves you with the understanding that every living thing on this planet is the current iteration of a process that has been going on for literally billions of years. He also doesn't shrink away from "political" topics — which of course, given that they are matters involving the survival of our species, are hardly political at all. I can't recommend this book highly enough.

Isn't it ironic enough to give Star ratings to the chap who taught us about stars? These mere 5 stars wouldn't even quantify the quality of his existence let alone his knowledge in our origin and evolution. What is lacking in this book? Nothing. It touches every branch of field that humans know. There is physics, chemistry, biology, astrology, astronomy, history, mathematics, geography, politics and even the psychology of humans. It not only includes the origin and evolution of the universe but also on the future of humans too. There's time travel too. This book is where we came from, what we are and what we might become. It let's you think for yourself. And if you watch the series along with this book, it will be the toping on the cake. Just as an afterthought, be prepared to be amazed and spooked and freaked out. I don't want to be a spoilsport by revealing too much about the book. Why don't you find it out for yourself?

There are books that you enjoy, there are books that make you think, and then there are books that make you wonder - Cosmos is one such book. Dr. Sagan's beautiful writing style filled me with awe and a resolve to keep exploring. From positrons to spaceships, from the golden days of the Alexandrian library to the present day, from the primordial soup to interstellar travel, from the lessons of our past to lessons for our future... Cosmos is a delightful, enriching read. I sincerely wish that it is made a part of the high school science syllabus for students across the world - one will benefit enormously from the lucid explanations of topics ranging from natural selection to hieroglyphics! One will begin to appreciate the enormous contributions made by thousands and thousands of generations to our "modern" lives... and, perhaps, one will also be motivated to think of answers to questions like how many inhabitable planets there could be in the universe, and, "Who speaks for Earth"?

I loved this book. Not only does it discuss the universe, but it talks about the history of scientific progress and the possibility of coming into contact with other civilizations in space. Keep in mind that this book was published in 1980, so there is a lot of "proposed" ideas and hopes by Sagan that have since been realized (and a lot of talk about the Soviet Union which, for some reason, made me giggle...). "The Cosmos may be densely populated with intelligent beings. But the Darwinian lesson is clear: There will be no humans elsewhere. Only here. Only on this small planet. We are a rare as well as an endangered species. Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you not find another."

Cosmos is a beautifully illustrated religious manifesto. The content is a selective history of science, couched in religious language, such as the first sentence "The Cosmos is all that is or was or ever will be," a pretty direct challenge to "In the beginning." I was most disappointed in Sagan's dishonesty as a historian of Christianity: the Church gets dragged through the mud for antagonizing Galileo, but the Big Bang goes uncredited throughout the book, as if Sagan didn't know that it had been discovered by a Catholic priest.

Favourite quotes:"Books break the shackles of time, proof that humans are magic.""I think the health of our civilization, the depth of our awareness about the underpinnings of our culture and our concern for the future can all be tested by how well we support our libraries."The bit about whether or not we are evolving fast enough to not use our evolving technology for war and whatnot.Most of the last chapter."Many of the stars in Orion are hot and young, evolving rapidly and ending their lives in colossal cosmic explosions called supernovae." - I dunno, it made me laugh.I also love how the Cheshire Cat defies gravity in that illustration.

He said so many things in a book so little that when I was reading about his opinion on nuclear weapons and political stuff I was wordless. How Sagan?

In Cosmos, Carl Sagan, through accessible, elegantly romantic prose, takes us on a journey to the stars and imparts on us a very important lesson: that science and mathematics are just as beautiful as the arts. This book is an essential read for anyone who wishes to appreciate the world we live in. People don’t generally associate science with poetry, but the healthy dose of romanticism in Cosmos makes the connection undeniable. Paired with empirical knowledge, concise explanations, and vision, it is undoubtedly one of the best scientific works of the generation. And Sagan, with his vast experience and understanding of the cosmos, his enthusiasm regarding it, and, most importantly, his humble acceptance of the fact that we, as humans, are nothing more than a blip on the cosmic radar - is the perfect narrator for this work. He takes vastly complicated concepts and simplifies them, enough so that anyone, even the epitome of the layman (myself) can understand, learn about, and wonder at the universe right alongside the professionals. This review doesn’t do Cosmos any justice. Please read this book. It is not often that one as amazing as this one comes along. It touched upon so many subjects that I feel as though, after finishing it, I have briefly glimpsed a snapshot of the world; it’s science, history, politics, and philosophy - all in the space of 384 pages.

I love this book. I bought it again (what universe do books you once owned get off to?) to remind myself of Sagan's brain and how he thought about the cosmos. And to a girl scifi nerd, this was an important caveat. Of course, there was no 3rd grade on Mars! Of course there weren't boy bullies, and music lessons, and teachers who needed to be doing something else for a living. Perhaps a planet with silica beings, or gas giants who floated in the methane winds of Jupiter. Maybe salt plain beings: maybe Lot's wife was zapped in a fly-by incident? Or an amoeba immersed in a boiling pool of compounds on Venus, contemplating how lucky and alone it is. Or molten rock DNA strands on Mercury, slithering through the cracks in the crust. Why is our armature calcium on an aluminum-rich planet? What would a girl look like on Neptune? Are there girls on Neptune? I love this book. It's a great gift for every dreaming youngster who shows signs of waiting for their mother ship to take them home.

It took me a month to finish this, partly because of real life, but also because, in a sense, this is a book that was not meant to be taken lightly. This is a book written with the utmost care, and you have to respect such books when you encountered one. I know a great book when I read one. Cosmos was a great book.I'm not sure if "great" was the right word, actually; "profoundly moving" might be more appopriate, though I suspect a lot of people have used quite the same vocabulary when describing this book. Cosmos and its illustrious author--Carl Sagan--did touch the life of many people, after all, and with perfectly good reasons. Sagan was eloquent, a master of words; he directed complex ideas and concepts like a conductor directed an orchestra. The end result was a beautiful symphony of ideas, masterfully conveyed and illustrated. I think it's no secret that science is daunting. I can't be the only one who thinks that. Sagan even stated in the last chapter that "...science and learning is the privilege of the few." How much of the state of things that we didn't know, because that door was barred from us, in one way or another? How many lights, how many curiosities, was extinguished? I think there was this post on Tumblr which basically stated, "It disappointed me how much math I need to get close to the stars", and I can forever relate to that post. A serious career in astronomy/space science/etc aside, it still takes you a lot of brainpower to even venture lightly to the world of science. But Carl Sagan was deemed as the man who brings science to the public with very, very good reason. Thanks to Cosmos, I can finally understand how fission process works, how atoms was formed, and the theory of relativity, among other things. I was educated in the best private schools of my part of the city, ended up a Social Studies major because I can't keep up with the rigorous demands of science (I excelled in Biology, though). Someone told me on Tumblr that this book has been very formative to them as a child. This is one of those interesting "fork points" in time that Sagan also mentioned--which spawned a dozen sci-fi plots--which immediately struck me: What if I found this book sooner? What if I've had a teacher like Sagan?We are all not as stupid (and conversely, not as smart or wise) as we often make ourselves to be. We so often downplayed our strengths, forever underselling our worth, in a culture that despises self-love and self-understanding. What Cosmos taught me was not only mere scientific facts, or how science works, but also a vast restructuring of my own thoughts. All my life I was told (and I told myself) that I'm bad at hard sciences. But reading this book, it makes me realised that I am not as stupid as I have so tirelessly convinced myself. Cosmos taught myself that I'm limitless, that if I applied myself I could accomplish great things, that my limitations sometimes can be pushed back. At the same time, it also taught me empathy and compassion that no self-help book ever could (not that I read a lot of those, I despised those). The pursuit of knowledge could solve a lot of problems that mankind faced. It's a fact. And the more I understand, the more reluctant I am to accept what my family and society has bequeathed to me, which is a bunch of R-Complex influenced ideology and mysticism. There is no such thing as an alien, within ourselves. We are all variations of the same idea, various applications of that idea. I might be too late and too old to go on a STEM track, but I think the last chapter might have inspired me to take up the second degree scholarship offer on Disruptive Innovation. We all deserved a better life.Anyway, back on track, I would say that this is a very dangerous book. I would say that this is the sort of book who will inspire you to become more, to dream bigger, because the Universe out there is waiting. And the alternative is nothing.I was, for lack of a better term, touched by Carl Sagan's tremendous humanity. Books are our own portable sort of magic--in his own words--and his book might be one of the greatest of them all. You could probably call this a how-to book on being a human, rather than a science manual. I can see how his thoughts have influenced people like Sir Arthur C Clarke, and it was thrilling, to read Cosmos in the 21st century and know that some of the ideas he had proposed, back in the Cold War era, like a vehicle to explore Mars, has come to pass. I wondered what Cosmos would sound like, had Sagan was still alive. I wondered how Sagan would react, if he was still alive. I think he was possibly delighted--that we had survived the Cold War fork in history without obliterating ourselves--but at the same time, he would probably be horrified at all the divisive ideologies and movements circulating around.I think a call for unity has never been uttered so eloquently, or so rationally. Cosmos is a book you must, hopefully, devote some time of your life to. It will profoundly transform your life.

It took me a month to finish this, partly because of real life, but also because, in a sense, this is a book that was not meant to be taken lightly. This is a book written with the utmost care, and you have to respect such books when you encountered one. I know a great book when I read one. Cosmos was a great book.I'm not sure if "great" was the right word, actually; "profoundly moving" might be more appopriate, though I suspect a lot of people have used quite the same vocabulary when describing this book. Cosmos and its illustrious author--Carl Sagan--did touch the life of many people, after all, and with perfectly good reasons. Sagan was eloquent, a master of words; he directed complex ideas and concepts like a conductor directed an orchestra. The end result was a beautiful symphony of ideas, masterfully conveyed and illustrated. I think it's no secret that science is daunting. I can't be the only one who thinks that. Sagan even stated in the last chapter that "...science and learning is the privilege of the few." How much of the state of things that we didn't know, because that door was barred from us, in one way or another? How many lights, how many curiosities, was extinguished? I think there was this post on Tumblr which basically stated, "It disappointed me how much math I need to get close to the stars", and I can forever relate to that post. A serious career in astronomy/space science/etc aside, it still takes you a lot of brainpower to even venture lightly to the world of science. But Carl Sagan was deemed as the man who brings science to the public with very, very good reason. Thanks to Cosmos, I can finally understand how fission process works, how atoms was formed, and the theory of relativity, among other things. I was educated in the best private schools of my part of the city, ended up a Social Studies major because I can't keep up with the rigorous demands of science (I excelled in Biology, though). Someone told me on Tumblr that this book has been very formative to them as a child. This is one of those interesting "fork points" in time that Sagan also mentioned--which spawned a dozen sci-fi plots--which immediately struck me: What if I found this book sooner? What if I've had a teacher like Sagan?We are all not as stupid (and conversely, not as smart or wise) as we often make ourselves to be. We so often downplayed our strengths, forever underselling our worth, in a culture that despises self-love and self-understanding. What Cosmos taught me was not only mere scientific facts, or how science works, but also a vast restructuring of my own thoughts. All my life I was told (and I told myself) that I'm bad at hard sciences. But reading this book, it makes me realised that I am not as stupid as I have so tirelessly convinced myself. Cosmos taught myself that I'm limitless, that if I applied myself I could accomplish great things, that my limitations sometimes can be pushed back. At the same time, it also taught me empathy and compassion that no self-help book ever could (not that I read a lot of those, I despised those). The pursuit of knowledge could solve a lot of problems that mankind faced. It's a fact. And the more I understand, the more reluctant I am to accept what my family and society has bequeathed to me, which is a bunch of R-Complex influenced ideology and mysticism. There is no such thing as an alien, within ourselves. We are all variations of the same idea, various applications of that idea. I might be too late and too old to go on a STEM track, but I think the last chapter might have inspired me to take up the second degree scholarship offer on Disruptive Innovation. We all deserved a better life.Anyway, back on track, I would say that this is a very dangerous book. I would say that this is the sort of book who will inspire you to become more, to dream bigger, because the Universe out there is waiting. And the alternative is nothing.I was, for lack of a better term, touched by Carl Sagan's tremendous humanity. Books are our own portable sort of magic--in his own words--and his book might be one of the greatest of them all. You could probably call this a how-to book on being a human, rather than a science manual. I can see how his thoughts have influenced people like Sir Arthur C Clarke, and it was thrilling, to read Cosmos in the 21st century and know that some of the ideas he had proposed, back in the Cold War era, like a vehicle to explore Mars, has come to pass. I wondered what Cosmos would sound like, had Sagan was still alive. I wondered how Sagan would react, if he was still alive. I think he was possibly delighted--that we had survived the Cold War fork in history without obliterating ourselves--but at the same time, he would probably be horrified at all the divisive ideologies and movements circulating around.I think a call for unity has never been uttered so eloquently, or so rationally. Cosmos is a book you must, hopefully, devote some time of your life to. It will profoundly transform your life.

I approached this book with fear and trembling; while I knew much of the discoveries were outdated and science has revealed so much more about the universe, I revere Sagan as one of the few geniuses that see the big picture and can articulate it. in my earlier, restless, seeking years, I learned this lesson in the deserts of Utah: “Science is not only compatible with spirituality; it is a profound source of spirituality.” There are people with no sense of spiritual life, no sense of the soul, no sense of mystery, but that impoverished worldview usually disintegrates when faced with the red rock of Utah, or the Grand Canyon, or illness, or cancer, or death, and then it can be transformed if natural, human curiosity is allowed to flourish. How can Utah look like Mars, is this what Mars looks like? What what forces and time caused the Grand Canyon? Why suffering? How do we die peacefully? If you never wonder about those things, none of them, bless you with TV, I hope you never run out of mindless things to watch. The sense of wonder is more powerful than any drug, I promise, and the high never ends. Today we have discovered a powerful and elegant way to understand the universe, a method called science; it has revealed to us a universe so ancient and so vast that human affairs seem at first sight to be of little consequence. We have grown distant from the Cosmos. It has seemed remote and irrelevant to everyday concerns. But science has found not only that the universe has a reeling and ecstatic grandeur, not only that it is accessible to human understanding, but also that we are, in a very real and profound sense, a part of that Cosmos, born from it, our fate deeply connected with it. The most basic human events and the most trivial trace back to the universe and its origins.In addition, science is a delight; evolution has arranged that we take pleasure in understanding—those who understand are more likely to survive. Science is an ongoing process. It never ends. There is no single ultimate truth to be achieved, after which all the scientists can retire. And because this is so, the world is far more interesting, both for the scientists and for the millions of people in every nation who, while not professional scientists, are deeply interested in the methods and findings of science. Lost somewhere between immensity and eternity is our tiny planetary home. They remind us that humans have evolved to wonder, that understanding is a joy, that knowledge is prerequisite to survival. The only typical place is within the vast, cold, universal vacuum, the everlasting night of intergalactic space, a place so strange and desolate that, by comparison, planets and stars and galaxies seem achingly rare and lovely. If we were randomly inserted into the Cosmos, the chance that we would find ourselves on or near a planet would be less than one in a billion trillion trillion* (1033, a one followed by 33 zeroes). In everyday life such odds are called compelling. Worlds are precious. Human beings grew up in forests; we have a natural affinity for them. How lovely a tree is, straining toward the sky. Its leaves harvest sunlight to photosynthesize, so trees compete by shadowing their neighbors. If you look closely you can often see two trees pushing and shoving with languid grace. Trees are great and beautiful machines, powered by sunlight, taking in water from the ground and carbon dioxide from the air, converting these materials into food for their use and ours. The plant uses the carbohydrates it makes as an energy source to go about its planty business. And we animals, who are ultimately parasites on the plants, steal the carbohydrates so we can go about our business. In eating the plants we combine the carbohydrates with oxygen dissolved in our blood because of our penchant for breathing air, and so extract the energy that makes us go. In the process we exhale carbon dioxide, which the plants then recycle to make more carbohydrates. What a marvelous cooperative arrangement—plants and animals each inhaling the other’s exhalations, a kind of planet-wide mutual mouth-to-stoma resuscitation, the entire elegant cycle powered by a star 150 million kilometers away. We today can recognize the antiquity of astrology in words such as disaster, which is Greek for “bad star,” influenza, Italian for (astral) “influence”; mazeltov, Hebrew—and, ultimately, Babylonian—for “good constellation,” or the Yiddish word shlamazel, applied to someone plagued by relentless ill-fortune, which again traces to the Babylonian astronomical lexicon. On Venus, on Earth and elsewhere in the solar system, there is evidence for catastrophic destruction, tempered or overwhelmed by slower, more uniform processes: on the Earth, for example, rainfall, coursing into rivulets, streams and rivers of running water, creating huge alluvial basins; on Mars, the remnants of ancient rivers, perhaps arising from beneath the ground; on Io, a moon of Jupiter, what seem to be broad channels made by flowing liquid sulfur. There are mighty weather systems on the Earth—and in the high atmosphere of Venus and on Jupiter. There are sandstorms on the Earth and on Mars; lightning on Jupiter and Venus and Earth. We inhabit a universe where atoms are made in the centers of stars; where each second a thousand suns are born; where life is sparked by sunlight and lightning in the airs and waters of youthful planets; where the raw material for biological evolution is sometimes made by the explosion of a star halfway across the Milky Way; where a thing as beautiful as a galaxy is formed a hundred billion times—a Cosmos of quasars and quarks, snowflakes and fireflies, where there may be black holes and other universes and extraterrestrial civilizations whose radio messages are at this moment reaching the Earth. How pallid by comparison are the pretensions of superstition and pseudoscience; how important it is for us to pursue and understand science, that characteristically human endeavor. Every aspect of Nature reveals a deep mystery and touches our sense of wonder and awe. Theophrastus was right. Those afraid of the universe as it really is, those who pretend to nonexistent knowledge and envision a Cosmos centered on human beings will prefer the fleeting comforts of superstition. They avoid rather than confront the world. But those with the courage to explore the weave and structure of the Cosmos, even where it differs profoundly from their wishes and prejudices, will penetrate its deepest mysteries. Alexandria was the greatest city the Western world had ever seen. People of all nations came there to live, to trade, to learn. On any given day, its harbors were thronged with merchants, scholars and tourists. This was a city where Greeks, Egyptians, Arabs, Syrians, Hebrews, Persians, Nubians, Phoenicians, Italians, Gauls and Iberians exchanged merchandise and ideas. It is probably here that the word cosmopolitan realized its true meaning—citizen, not just of a nation, but of the Cosmos,*  this: For unknown ages after the explosive outpouring of matter and energy of the Big Bang, the Cosmos was without form. There were no galaxies, no planets, no life. Deep, impenetrable darkness was everywhere, hydrogen atoms in the void. Here and there denser accumulations of gas were imperceptibly growing, globes of matter were condensing—hydrogen raindrops more massive than suns. Within these globes of gas was first kindled the nuclear fire latent in matter. A first generation of stars was born, flooding the Cosmos with light. There were in those times not yet any planets to receive the light, no living creatures to admire the radiance of the heavens. Deep in the stellar furnaces the alchemy of nuclear fusion created heavy elements, the ashes of hydrogen burning, the atomic building materials of future planets and lifeforms. Massive stars soon exhausted their stores of nuclear fuel. Rocked by colossal explosions, they returned most of their substance back into the thin gas from which they had once condensed. Here in the dark lush clouds between the stars, new raindrops made of many elements were forming, later generations of stars being born. Nearby, smaller raindrops grew, bodies far too little to ignite the nuclear fire, droplets in the interstellar mist on their way to form the planets. Among them was a small world of stone and iron, the early Earth. Congealing and warming, the Earth released the methane, ammonia, water and hydrogen gases that had been trapped within, forming the primitive atmosphere and the first oceans. Starlight from the Sun bathed and warmed the primeval Earth, drove storms, generated lightning and thunder. Volcanoes overflowed with lava. These processes disrupted molecules of the primitive atmosphere; the fragments fell back together again into more and more complex forms, which dissolved in the early oceans. After a time the seas achieved the consistency of a warm, dilute soup. Molecules were organized, and complex chemical reactions driven, on the surface of clays. And one day a molecule arose that quite by accident was able to make crude copies of itself out of the other molecules in the broth. As time passed, more elaborate and more accurate self-replicating molecules arose. Those combinations best suited to further replication were favored by the sieve of natural selection. Those that copied better produced more copies. And the primitive oceanic broth gradually grew thin as it was consumed by and transformed into complex condensations of self-replicating organic molecules. Gradually, imperceptibly, life had begun. Single-celled plants evolved, and life began to generate its own food. Photosynthesis transformed the atmosphere. Sex was invented. Once free-living forms banded together to make a complex cell with specialized functions. Chemical receptors evolved, and the Cosmos could taste and smell. One-celled organisms evolved into multicellular colonies, elaborating their various parts into specialized organ systems. Eyes and ears evolved, and now the Cosmos could see and hear. Plants and animals discovered that the land could support life. Organisms buzzed, crawled, scuttled, lumbered, glided, flapped, shimmied, climbed and soared. Colossal beasts thundered through the steaming jungles. Small creatures emerged, born live instead of in hard-shelled containers, with a fluid like the early oceans coursing through their veins. They survived by swiftness and cunning. And then, only a moment ago, some small arboreal animals scampered down from the trees. They became upright and taught themselves the use of tools, domesticated other animals, plants and fire, and devised language. The ash of stellar alchemy was now emerging into consciousness. At an ever-accelerating pace, it invented writing, cities, art and science, and sent spaceships to the planets and the stars. These are some of the things that hydrogen atoms do, given fifteen billion years of cosmic evolution. It has the sound of epic myth, and rightly. But it is simply a description of cosmic evolution as revealed by the science of our time. We are difficult to come by and a danger to ourselves. But any account of cosmic evolution makes it clear that all the creatures of the Earth, the latest manufactures of the galactic hydrogen industry, are beings to be cherished. Elsewhere there may be other equally astonishing transmutations of matter, so wistfully we listen for a humming in the sky. We have held the peculiar notion that a person or society that is a little different from us, whoever we are, is somehow strange or bizarre, to be distrusted or loathed. Think of the negative connotations of words like alien or outlandish. And yet the monuments and cultures of each of our civilizations merely represent different ways of being human. An extraterrestrial visitor, looking at the differences among human beings and their societies, would find those differences trivial compared to the similarities. The Cosmos may be densely populated with intelligent beings. But the Darwinian lesson is clear: There will be no humans elsewhere. Only here. Only on this small planet. We are a rare as well as an endangered species. Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another. Human history can be viewed as a slowly dawning awareness that we are members of a larger group. Initially our loyalties were to ourselves and our immediate family, next, to bands of wandering hunter-gatherers, then to tribes, small settlements, city-states, nations. We have broadened the circle of those we love. We have now organized what are modestly described as superpowers, which include groups of people from divergent ethnic and cultural backgrounds working in some sense together—surely a humanizing and character-building experience. If we are to survive, our loyalties must be broadened further, to include the whole human community, the entire planet Earth. Many of those who run the nations will find this idea unpleasant. They will fear the loss of power. We will hear much about treason and disloyalty. Rich nation-states will have to share their wealth with poor ones. But the choice, as H. G. Wells once said in a different context, is clearly the universe or nothing.
