Carl Sagan's "Cosmos" is a something that isn't supposed to be left by the wayside. On the surface, Cosmos is about science. From the very small cells, to the universe itself, the book covers a bit of everything through the lens of the discoverer. Beyond the surface, Cosmos offers much much more. It offers an insight a Carl Sagan himself. Sagan clearly had a vision of the universe around him and was able to think vastly differently then many others. He could envision worlds which would seem impossible, but through science and observation, could very well exist. Sagan wasn't an American, he was an Earthling. Sagan understood that the borders we drew around ourselves were arbitrary compared to the reality. In the last chapter Sagan's understanding of the world clearly comes into view. While the outlook of humanity seems very doomed, he still holds optimism. Upon watching the television series with the same title, I though that perhaps Sagan was a bit preachy in his antiwar speech, but after reading this book, I can see where he comes from. It the fact that the story shaped by the cosmos, viewed through we humans, could be destroyed in only a few seconds because we haven't decided to evolve into something better. If you want to read this for the science, you may find yourself a bit disappointed and scared (because sometimes his ideas and theories are a bit cryptic, e.g. global warming). But, if you want to view the world through a new lens, to wrap your mind around something new and garner a new hue for the world, I would highly suggest this for your reading. In all honesty, my words are meaningless when trying to explain the great contribution the Sagan has attempted to inject into society (and sadly ignored for more "pop culture" garbage). Carl Sagan was a great man in life and can certainly find immortality in his words.

This book is so packed with information, I really had to pace myself in order to digest it all. Some of the science is outdated, but the history of our understanding of the cosmos and space exploration section, as well as Sagan's musings on what the future holds for us Homo sapiens here on earth and our place in the universe are well worth it. The book also needs some subheadings or something, the length of the chapters was a little exhausting and Sagan's writing meandered at times. Sagan has such an incredible understanding of how our planet fits into the universe - he is able to divorce himself of all earthly bias and the limitations of human intuition to grasp the vast timescales and contradictions of astrophysics and come to clear conclusions. He writes from an almost extra-terrestrial viewpoint, writing objectively about mankind's follies and failings in a way that reminds me a little of the condescending tone BBC reporters use to talk about the United States' irrational gun laws or healthcare system. And the way he breaks down the probability of discovering intelligent life elsewhere in the universe is so systematic, thorough, and logically consistent, it gave me the chills! I also loved his perspective on intra-planetary relations, ie how humans in different regions should treat one another given our understanding of our cosmic uniqueness and the common goals of mankind. I felt some real shame as a human when Sagan explained how for the price of a couple nuclear submarines we could double the national space exploration budget. Instead of taking turns blowing things up we could channel human ingenuity and resources towards the more ennobling goals of expanding the cosmic footprint of mankind. Much simpler said than done, but Sagan states the obvious so eloquently that you want to shout it from the rooftops.

OK, it took me time to read this one but not because it was boring but because it was simply brilliant. It is usually hard to read books written by scientists. I've always found them to be heavy on the science and very little thought is spared for the reader who might not be familiar with those concepts. Sagan stands out in this regard. The book is beautifully written. Sagan's prose is poetic. The book reads like an ode to the universe. Or like a passionate love letter. When you read the book, it becomes very evident to you that you are conversing with a mind that is so in love with the universe and everything in it; who is striving to understand even a grain's worth of it before his time is up. Sagan was a self- professed agnostic and I think that comes out very clearly in this book. He explains the science well but then when he expands his though process, you can feel his writing borders on a sense of awe an reverence for the universe. Sagan's writing is powerful. Many times, I had to catch my breath and read a line again; the impact was huge. With the most simple of words, Sagan weaves magic. He makes us realise how inconsequential we are in the grand scheme of things while at the same time telling us that we are all extraordinary, because we are all made of stars. Sagan has tried to resolve scientific concepts and human kind's awe for the universe in this book. He touches on everything from evolution, superstition, Kepler, relativity, planets, ancient scientists, nuclear war and the cosmos. He also handles concepts like religion, books, belief, intolerance and what not. Recommended reading for everyone. I read the e-version of the book, but I'm getting my hands on a hardbound version and its going on my bookshelf, and into the hands of my son as soon as he's old enough to understand at least parts of this. Absolutely breathtaking!!

The Cosmos is everything that was, that is and that will ever be. Carl Sagan takes us through this exquisite journey starting with the origins and evolution of life on earth, then about our endeavors to explore the inner solar system comprising of the venus and mars. He points out that just like the americas and india were unexplored centuries ago, when the only known land was europe, such is our current situation on the shores of the cosmic ocean- with lot of worlds to be explored yet. He opines that the next striking thing to dawn upon us will be the news of contact with an extra-terrestrial civilization and that he is eagerly awaiting for it. He also explains how he is humbled by the immensity of space and how worthless is our fight for little more space in this pitiable corner of the cosmos. He explains how man since the ancient times, was keen to know what those shiny little things were up above in the night sky, and also how knowing their cycles meant the difference between life and death for him. He praises the greek for their practical wisdom and contributions to astronomy. He also approves the indian mythological concept of cycles of creation and destruction. He also presents an alarming fact that once a civilization reaches a certain amount of scientific progress, it tends to destroy ourselves, and that it is an inevitability in our near future. In last few chapters he talks about travel to nearby stars. It was an exciting read. Those who are passionate about astronomy, our origins and man's explorations into space will really love it. Now that I have completed it, I am eagerly waiting for Christopher Nolan's Interstellar to get released!

It was truly an honour to read this book. I am so lucky to have been born after Carl Sagan, and to be born in a time when books can be published - more specifically, Carl Sagan's books. This book isn't just a favourite - it's a book I love.I don't really read non-fiction, so for people out there who don't either, this review is for you.Cosmos is a wonderful book that explores the origins of the universe and the origins of humanity at the same time. Carl Sagan is a wonderful writer who offers the reader a comprehensive understanding of the foundations of our universe, and the beginning of scientific thought. He reflects on the past of human beings, introduces us to theories about astronomy, and gives us hope for the future. Carl Sagan's words ignite the "starstuff" within you - truly.This book is a great read if you love learning. And if you don't, this book will make you love learning, and love reading, because Carl Sagan is a wonderful writer. He truly understands and appreciates the power of language, and it is evident in his writing. In some ways, he bares his thoughts to the reader - which is why you fall in love with distant galaxies and astronomy - because you can't help but see the universe through his eyes.And if you're not really interested in space, then that's okay. Because this book is also about the origins of humanity. Not just rational thought or science, but a lot of the milestones that made us who we are today. This book is both a museum of the universe and of the Earth - and I recommend it to lovers of reading, knowledge, science, history, or just anybody with a vested interest in humanity and its future.

I have hired this book from the local Astronomy Society library shelves, but also bought the full DVD series of what must be some of the finest t.v. ever made. So 30 years on I'm firstly watching one of the hour long programmes and then reading the relevant chapter in the book. I already know this is 5 star.Published in 1980 and based on Sagan's epic 13 part t.v. series, Cosmos is a remarkable journey. A trip for the mind and a meditation for the soul. Our travels into the Cosmos takes us through human history, from the Egyptian, Chinese and Greek early sciences into the European Enlightenment (or re-discovery). On to the 4 billion year formation of Hydrogen molecules into complex DNA, then off into space for a tour of the solar system. Sagan includes stops off the spaceship to hit the reader with Biology, or Ecology, or domesday scenarios of nuclear destruction. Then we're off to the stars again. The t.v. series is so good I'm only up to part 7, and each part I've watched twice. Carl Sagan is sadly missed. What this publication would have been with the images of Hubble! The book makes do with many fine paintings of solar and deep space subjects, but you feel Carl would have loved Hubble.Finally in the authors own words: The surface of the Earth is the shore of the cosmic ocean. From it we have learned most of what we know. Recently, we have waded a little out to sea, enough to dampen our toes or, at most, wet our ankles. The water seems inviting. The ocean calls. Some part of our being knows this is from where we came. We long to return.

This took a long time to get through, partly because it was so tempting to read it with Sagan's measured, stately narration as in the outstanding TV series. I also dragged my heels in the sections that most showed their age, such as the lengthy descriptions of the then-nascent Mars missions, the unknown cause of the extinction of the dinosaurs, and the calculation of sum totals of a species' information in terms of bits of data (he kindly defines for us what a bit is).I found myself wishing he hadn't passed away 15 years ago, as his voice is at once so rational and knowledgeable and so emotionally compelling that perhaps he is our species' best hope for sanity and peaceful cooperation--our best hope for a continuing future. Then again, precisely *because* he is able to channel his vision and understanding of the big picture to anyone who will stop to consider our place in the cosmos, his arguments will long outlive the both of us. This is ultimately the most powerful anti-war document I can imagine, written in the long shadow of nuclear proliferation. Even as he is clearly desperate for humanity to wake up to its possibilities, he delivers his message through such an unending awe for life on Earth that he is at once revered scientist and star-struck child--and he invites us to join him in both roles.I still prefer the raw power of the PBS series over the book (yes, even as the graphics have long since crossed over into the realm of cheese), but any devotee of the TV show would appreciate the chance to peruse the book at leisure.

Cosmos is a nonfiction book written by the award winning astronomer Carl Sagen, and it is considered to be a classic of astronomy. It covers many topics related to astronomy, from the beginning of the universe to the possibilities of life on other planets to the future of the human race in space, all of them are covered in detail and in easy to understand language.  The book, which was originally written in conjunction with the Cosmos TV series, is a very interesting journey into the world of astronomy, with brief descriptions of much of the contents so as to fit more into the book, essentially filling all the basics of astronomy and all studies related to it into one book. The book also makes an interesting use of a combination of religious ideas and metaphors into the normally squarely scientific area of astronomy. While I personally feel that this is not a good scientific principal, I can certainly see how it would lead to not only a better understanding but also an increased interest and acceptance of some of the ideas elsewhere in the book, along with the ones being discussed. I liked this book, especially how it condensed many different areas of astronomy and science in general into the one book, but still making it all fit and feel like one book. I did, however, feel that the book did not have a very clear layout of the chapters, and therefor felt slightly disorganized. I would recommend this book to anyone at all interested in almost any branch of science, especially astronomy.

In the life of a human being 30 years might seem as a lot of time, but compared to 30 years for modern science, it seems less than minuscule. A lot has happened since Cosmos was written and some of the theories expressed there are dated, some seemingly unanswerable questions have been answered and there are plenty of new pages of history to discover.That being said, I never approached reading Cosmos as a science book and I believe that nobody should. While it still contains some deal of dry science data (how many bits it was again, Mr. Sagan?), most of which is valid today as well, it is primary as popular-scientific book that succeeds more at being an intricate mixture of hard sciences - physics, chemistry, astronomy, biology - and different sub-types of philosophy, most notably metaphysics and cosmology with a great deal of history of science sprinkled on top for added value.As in most pop-sci books, the language is more than pleasant and allows the book to be read with ease, any science bits are described as simplified as possible and just like the TV-Series, Cosmos probably is the most quotable book I've encountered up to date.If I did not mind encroaching on people too much and I lived in a country where English was more widely spoken and I was more fanatical about science, I might go around preaching from it. Come to think of it, I might anyhow just for the laughs of it.

My mother gave this book to me when I was in the 1st grade and it was one of the biggest eye openers of my childhood. Even though at the time I didn't understand most of the scientific jargon, my fascination with outer space and the planets drew me in and I was hooked. By the 3rd grade I was giving oral reports on black holes and the fabric of space-time and boring the hell out of my friends with my nonstop space rants. I've re-read it at least 6 different times since then as well as numerous other books by Steven Hawking and Kirshner and I can honestly say this is the greatest book about outer space/civilization/technology that I have ever read. The speculative fiction/non-fiction elements blend together perfectly and there is a never ending source of independence to what you can get out of this book. This book is a look at the big picture, the universe. Written by debatably the smartest astrophysicist of all time, Carl Sagan understood the universe possibly more than any human being who has ever lived. This book is the "Space Bible". Don't watch the series until you have read the book, and make sure it's the coffee table edition. The tiny paperback edition doesn't do justice to the amazing paintings. Every home in the world should have a copy.

2.5★I read a book to learn something from. But this book just provides me with a surface level information on topics, which Mr. Sagan is passionate about, with some tinch of Philosophy. PS: I freaking love (or in other words, have an unhealthy obsession with) physics and maths.

This book is the most amazing and phenomenal and austouding book i have ever read!!!!  so deep and rich are the contents of this book, ranging from the birth of stars to how we humans are in danger of self destruction.  it consists of 13 chapters out of which my favourite chapters are "persistence of memory "and "who speaks for earth? "the others chapters were also great but these two chapters really spoke to me especially chapter 13. the chapter "who speaks for earth?" deals with humans life long attribute that is greed and how our greed for power have made destructive weapons like nuclear weapon whose effect had devestating impact on the world especially people of japan. the holocaust brought by our own power.who will stand up against things like this except we the people whom the cosmos gave birth to. we must stand up and speak for earth ,our earth and protect whatever is left of it.  this book has definitely impacted my perspective on life and where we stand as homosapiens and how we are all interconnected with one another though cosmic evolution. ❤❤❤❤i love this book to infinity And beyond. 💜💜💜💜👍👍

This book had been on my list for a while and in my possession even longer. I decided it would get bumped up to "on-deck" when I saw a stranger holding it and overheard her commenting to a friend: "I read Cosmos at least 1 time a year."Having read Cosmos, I won't read it once a year, but I will make an effort to re-read the book while I'm still a young adult and hopefully read it again at a later date beyond that. The material in this book is awe inspiring and Carl Sagan has a real gift for eloquence and for communicating complex ideas effectively. Admittedly, some of the info is just a bit too hard to grasp (the size of the Universe), and other info is simply recondite mainly b/c it's outside the realm of our experience (relativity)... but the book is still definately worth a go. This seems silly to mention but I was impressed with Sagan's knowledge of certain aspects of ancient times and his quoting of very old text. Overall as a reader you feel in very good hands; those of an intellectual virtuoso. I highly recommend the book to others.

In a single sentence, this is a balm in book form for an existential crisis. I was feeling lost and confused in this painful universe and searching for something on the order of magnitude of religion to believe in, but religion has always seemed inadequate. If you've ever felt yourself moved or compelled by science, this is it.My first introduction to Carl Sagan's Cosmos was by my 8th grade science teacher, who wrote the chemical equations for photosynthesis and cellular respiration on the blackboard, one above the other, and asked us to stare at it until we had realized the beauty of this wonderous cycle that nature had set up. He then read the passage to us (the one about the mouth-to-stoma resuscitation), and that was my first glimpse of Sagan's ability to convey profound observations about the beauty of the universe in such simple and elegant terms.I grabbed this off a used bookstore shelf in search of something to believe in, and devoured it in one night. Felt a little better about my existence, and that of our world, afterwards. Absolutely incredible.

Carl Sagan's beautiful words transform you to outside the earth, into the cosmos and lets you appreciate the grandeur of the universe. It has so many unforgettable quotes which makes you ponder simultaneously on how precious human race is and also how trivial it is in the big picture. I think this is a must read not only for every science enthusiast but also for every person to appreciate the very fact we are "alive" and "conscious" in this universe and in his words how we are "star stuff pondering stars". His pitch for disarmament of nuclear weapons and increased investment in the cosmic exploration in the last chapter is nothing short of a historic speech if it has really been delivered on some big platform. I think every Nation head needs to read the last chapter especially in today's world to understand how important it is for us to make right decisions in this age. Read the book to appreciate the Universe and Nature and the fact that you are the result of innumerable, highly unlikely things occurring at the right place and the right time.

This was truly a mind-expanding and thought-provoking book. Made me ponder over a lot of things. Carl Sagan takes you on a journey to the end of universe, he makes you think about the origin of our species, about the origin of our planet and what might our species do in the future. This book has made me look at things from a different perspective. This book has made me realise that our planet is not such a bad place after all. We are so lucky to be part of this rare planet and we must do everything to savour it. The world, the people , everything that you see around yourself is made from the elements that created the universe- the cosmos. To quote from the book : The cosmos may be densely populated with intelligent beings. But the Darwinian lesson is clear: There will be no humans elsewhere. Only here. Only on this small planet. We are a rare as well as an endangered species. Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another.

I found Cosmos to be an excellent, accessible introduction to a wide range of scientific discoveries from the past few centuries. I also appreciated how, despite the book's Western bent, Sagan incorporated pre-scientific ideas from several non-European cultures, to show how scientific discoveries are made in parallel.That said, I saw this book as more history than science — a history of science, yes, but still history. The benefit to this is that, although the book was published nearly 40 years ago, much of it still remains relevant; the downside to this is that it is not very in-depth, and the title felt misleading. Another downside, in my opinion, is that its philosophical musings were a bit tedious, but that's my personal taste.I would highly recommend this book for any non-STEM major friends that want to jump into scientific nonfiction but don't know where to start; otherwise, I would recommend Welcome to the Universe by Neil deGrasse Tyson for those looking for a more in-depth intro to astrophysics.

I picked up this book at the University of Chicago bookstore, and it is undoubtedly the best $20 that I have ever spent. Carl Sagan is not only a scientist, but a true humanitarian. His brilliant writing and compassionate narrative instilled in me a sense of awe and respect for science, the cosmos, and life. Every one of us is made of the elements from the stars, which are everywhere in the cosmos, but each human being is also the only instance of themself in the entire universe. Billions of billions of billions of atoms formed the cosmos, and the cosmos made the earth, and the earth made life, and humans. On a cosmic scale, warfare and animosity towards other members of our own species seem so trivial, yet they threaten the destruction of life that came from millions of years of painstaking evolution. In the cosmos, If we do not speak for earth, then no one will. And all of us together speak for earth. Seeing things from a cosmic perspective is humbling. I encourage you to go on a cosmic voyage with Carl Sagan, and set sail for the stars.

This is not just a sit-down-and-read-straight-through kind of book. It's more of a coffee table book, but that label tends to belittle its contents. This is a hugely eye-opening, all-encompassing coverage of the collective universe as experienced by the human race so far.The book's general theme, as with the TV series upon which it is based, is the uniqueness of human life in the midst of so much astrophysical indifference and chaos. The bulk of the text provides scientific facts about space, species, evolution, energy, motion, matter, and accompanying insight about the ramifications of said facts. But there seems to be an overarching message of existentialism - humanity holding its own fate in its hands. It encourages scientific inquiry and promotes a message of developing technology further for the purpose of educating ourselves further as living residents of a vast, mysterious universe, and how we might continue to survive as a species in such a volatile environment.

This should be required reading in schools. Its subject matter is focused on science but the telling of the story is so rich and embedded with historical and social commentary that makes it a gripping read and drives the pace along, despite being about something as lofty and uncommon in the average person's lives as astronomy. Carl Sagan makes astronomy and the sciences wholly approachable, while also contagiously spreading the nearly holy reverence he has for the cosmos, and rightly so. It reads like poetic literature, religious text, scientific briefing, philosophical tome, and a history of all existence. I was seriously blown away. It is hard to read this book and look at anything around us without a sense of connectedness and awe that we happen to exist as this bizarre collection of basic elements, each made distinct by electric and nuclear forces and an unfathomably long period of time, and are able to gather here and be able to read this book.

So I finished this last night/super early this morning (1 am) and am still slightly in awe. I've always enjoyed learning about space and the universe, but never really had the mathematical chops to make it into a real hobby. This book changed all that, and within an explanation of the history of astronomy, made it into a much more accessible area of study. I'm certainly not going to become an astronomer, but this book was eye-opening simply for how such complex concepts were re-written so as to be more easily understood. Science and scientists cannot remain in an ivory tower, and this book represents a concerted effort to remove that and make astronomy open to many. But what mostly struck me was the way that Dr. Sagan contextualized humans and their conflicts within the universe. He draws a picture of humans as simply an evolution of the cosmos, that we as a species are something both far lesser and far greater than how we view ourselves.

This has been one of the most acclaimed books of the recent past and with good reason. I was pleasantly surprised at how relevant this book still is after decades of publication. Carl Sagan has done an excellent job of explaining the wonders of the cosmos in a language simple enough for a lay person to understand and appreciate. I have a fairly decent understanding and interest in the sciences and understood that the universe is immense and amazing. In spite of this, I was amazed at the magnitude of the universe in terms of distances and time which Sagan was able to convey in terms that one could easily relate to. This book gave me a new found appreciation for our planet, our lives and the very little time we have. Highly recommended. PS: I was lucky to get one of the editions with color illustrations and photographs, which really helps visualize the wonders that you are reading about.

I wish I was so lucky to have read this book as a child - or even as a teenager. I would have become an astronomer, no doubt about it. But I still feel very lucky to have read it. So maybe I will still.This is the book that should be taught in every school in every corner of the world, so we all have a chance to broaden our horizons no matter which primitive political system we are trapped in. If this book has tiny flaws or if the romanticism is found overpowering at times - it matters not, as the ideas gathered are enourmous and beautiful and incredibly inspiring. There is a reason Carl Sagan and Cosmos moved so many.I've so far gifted the book to three people, one of whom has already read it. I will keep doing the same with as many people as I can. I want them to get to know themselves, the matter and the void and be awed and inspired by the gigantic and the subatomic like I did.

Carl Sagan to be honest I'll write it in a very brief way ,allow me to tell that this book and the heavy details invaded every atom or more precisely every quark of my body Thank you very much for this treasure !! _______________________We have held the peculiar notion that a person or society that is a little different from us, whoever we are, is somehow strange or bizarre, to be distrusted or loathed. Think of the negative connotations of words like alien or outlandish. And yet the monuments and cultures of each of our civilizations merely represent different ways of being human. An extraterrestrial visitor, looking at the differences among human beings and their societies, would find those differences trivial compared to the similarities. The Cosmos may be densely populated with intelligent beings.

"Cosmos, an inescapable perspective awaits us. There are not yet any obvious signs of extraterrestrial intelligence and this makes us wonder whether civilizations like ours always rush implacably, headlong, toward self-destruction. National boundaries are not evident when we view the Earth from space. Fanatical ethic or religious or national chauvinisms are a little difficult to maintain when we see our planet as a fragile blue crescent fading to become an inconspicuous point of light against the bastion and citadel of the stars. Travel is broadening. There are worlds on which life has never arisen. There are worlds that have been charred and ruined by cosmic catastrophes. We are fortunate: we are alive, we are powerful ; the welfare of our civilization and our species is in our hands. If we do not speak for Earth, who will? If we are not committed to our own survival, who will be?' "

How many people can say that their life was shaped by a documentary? Of those, how many can say that the documentary shaped them in not one, but three ways? Dr. Carl Sagan's award winning series introduced me to science, history and the history of science, and the music of Vangelis. I was only four or five when I first watched this show on PBS and it enthralled me.Today I'm a historian and one of my specialties is the history of science. I'm a new age musician and my musical compositions are heavily influenced by the work of Vangelis. And I'm an amateur astronomer with a passion for exo-solar planets, a subject Dr. Sagan speaks about frequently during the series.It remains a classic of scientific writing and a icon of documentary excellence.

I remember watching this television series on PBS when it aired originally back in 1980. So here's the deal. Sagan was a die-hard atheist and I am a sold-out Christian. I disagree with him vehemently on just about every page—sometimes (depending on the chapter) maybe even every sentence. But his style is so engaging, and the material he brings together (especially the history) is just so dang captivatingly interesting, I can't help myself. (I first learned what a googol and a googolplex were from him, for crying out loud. That, at least, is worth a little love.) If you have the right grid to filter all the information through (i.e. a good grounding in Christian apologetics and worldview discourse) there's actually a good deal here to appreciate.

I am in my early 40s, and am a chemical engineer with an amateur interesting in astronomy and physics. Coming from this background, there were a few parts in here in which Sagan talks about things that were new to me, but overall he was talking about fairly basic stuff. I think the audience intended is for either younger readers or readers who haven't already done much or any reading about astronomy. Sagan's passion for astronomy and his interest in the search for extraterrestrial life comes through in an exciting way. Early on in the book Sagan makes a few derogatory comments about religion that I just ignored because I realize that they is obligatory in any popular science book, but they just keep coming. In fact, he seems to get rather preachy about about how backward, oppressed and uninformed believers in God are. This aspect of the book was, in fact, one of the things that kept me going . . . I wanted to see just how outspoken he would get. I won't take the time to give quotes and refute specific arguments from a decades-old book, but I will say that Sagan seemed to have fallen trap to what I believe to be the logical fallacy of assuming that all of religion is incorrect because certain aspects of it don't correspond with our observations . . . one example is the apparent contradiction between what the book of Genesis seems to be saying about the age of the earth and what can be seen in the geological and fossil record. Using reasons like this to conclude that there is no God and Jesus Christ is not good science.I cannot deny that many horrible things have been done over the centuries in the name of religion, but I have read enough history to believe that religion, per se, is not the cause. The cause is that most people have a tendency to be selfish and hate those that are different. Abolishing religion will not root this tendency out of people; there will simply be terrible atrocities perpetrated in the name of something else.I gave the book three stars because it was written well enough to really get me to think about some things. But it is too mixed with anti-religious propaganda to be really considered a science book, as I believe it is marketed.

I don't know how to exactly review this.It's a love story. It's like listening to a love letter written to a dear friend about the writer's love of his life. The writer being Carl Sagan and the love of his life being The cosmos. (and also his wife, who gets one of my favorite dedications ever). As hackneyed as that sounds I really can't describe this book better in another way. The most compelling thing about this book is Sagan's love of space, earth, what makes us who and what we are and what we can be. It is one of the most enjoyable experiences one can have learning something. I love space. I love learning about it. And all the elements that make it up. I think mainly this is because astronomers seem to have an infectious love of their subject. Sagan gave such a love to Neil Degrasse Tyson (who opens the audio book I listened to) and Tyson has shared that with my generation including myself. Which is what lead me to go back to the source. I've seen Sagan's cosmos show in its entirety and this is part covering the same ground and a companion of said show. The book makes you feel infinitely small, yet infinitely important. The subject is taught in such a way that it's easily approachable and immensely interesting. I think I will definitely read more by Sagan. I love his poetic tone and his ability to express and impart ideas. I usually read via audiobooks and normally I don't review them as such on here, but I want to shout out this aspect for this particular book. Sagan's wife Ann Druyan wrote and narrated one introduction. Tyson another. And Seth McFarlane (who's work I mostly dislike but who I deeply respect for ensuring Tyson's updated Cosmos tv show exists) reads Sagan's original intro. The body of the book is read by one of my childhood heroes who helped instill my love of reading, LeVar Burton. This audio book is a work of art. So relaxing and all encompassing. As a finished listening I was already excited to listen to it again. I may start falling asleep to it or something. It's such a great production.

This is one of the most amazing, eye-opening book I've ever read, besides The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy. The prose is simple yet enlightening. It's incredible how something so complicated could be so simple in his words.I picked this book us because I read The Sun Is Also a Star and it contained a little bit of Sagan gem in the beginning and I knew that I had to look it up. I swear it's not because I liked apple pie. Last Sunday I was having the most rotten day and my problems are piling higher and higher and as far as a bookworm goes, a bookstore is the cure. Saw Cosmos on sale so I began to read it almost immediately. Funny thing about something intangible and as far as infinite goes, all of my problems disappeared. I solved one problem on the same day. Today I solve another one. I will solve another problem later. I'm half human, half universe. I got this.

Carl Sagan's "Cosmos" is a something that isn't supposed to be left by the wayside. On the surface, Cosmos is about science. From the very small cells, to the universe itself, the book covers a bit of everything through the lens of the discoverer. Beyond the surface, Cosmos offers much much more. It offers an insight a Carl Sagan himself. Sagan clearly had a vision of the universe around him and was able to think vastly differently then many others. He could envision worlds which would seem impossible, but through science and observation, could very well exist. Sagan wasn't an American, he was an Earthling. Sagan understood that the borders we drew around ourselves were arbitrary compared to the reality. In the last chapter Sagan's understanding of the world clearly comes into view. While the outlook of humanity seems very doomed, he still holds optimism. Upon watching the television series with the same title, I though that perhaps Sagan was a bit preachy in his antiwar speech, but after reading this book, I can see where he comes from. It the fact that the story shaped by the cosmos, viewed through we humans, could be destroyed in only a few seconds because we haven't decided to evolve into something better. If you want to read this for the science, you may find yourself a bit disappointed and scared (because sometimes his ideas and theories are a bit cryptic, e.g. global warming). But, if you want to view the world through a new lens, to wrap your mind around something new and garner a new hue for the world, I would highly suggest this for your reading. In all honesty, my words are meaningless when trying to explain the great contribution the Sagan has attempted to inject into society (and sadly ignored for more "pop culture" garbage). Carl Sagan was a great man in life and can certainly find immortality in his words.

This book is so packed with information, I really had to pace myself in order to digest it all. Some of the science is outdated, but the history of our understanding of the cosmos and space exploration section, as well as Sagan's musings on what the future holds for us Homo sapiens here on earth and our place in the universe are well worth it. The book also needs some subheadings or something, the length of the chapters was a little exhausting and Sagan's writing meandered at times. Sagan has such an incredible understanding of how our planet fits into the universe - he is able to divorce himself of all earthly bias and the limitations of human intuition to grasp the vast timescales and contradictions of astrophysics and come to clear conclusions. He writes from an almost extra-terrestrial viewpoint, writing objectively about mankind's follies and failings in a way that reminds me a little of the condescending tone BBC reporters use to talk about the United States' irrational gun laws or healthcare system. And the way he breaks down the probability of discovering intelligent life elsewhere in the universe is so systematic, thorough, and logically consistent, it gave me the chills! I also loved his perspective on intra-planetary relations, ie how humans in different regions should treat one another given our understanding of our cosmic uniqueness and the common goals of mankind. I felt some real shame as a human when Sagan explained how for the price of a couple nuclear submarines we could double the national space exploration budget. Instead of taking turns blowing things up we could channel human ingenuity and resources towards the more ennobling goals of expanding the cosmic footprint of mankind. Much simpler said than done, but Sagan states the obvious so eloquently that you want to shout it from the rooftops.

OK, it took me time to read this one but not because it was boring but because it was simply brilliant. It is usually hard to read books written by scientists. I've always found them to be heavy on the science and very little thought is spared for the reader who might not be familiar with those concepts. Sagan stands out in this regard. The book is beautifully written. Sagan's prose is poetic. The book reads like an ode to the universe. Or like a passionate love letter. When you read the book, it becomes very evident to you that you are conversing with a mind that is so in love with the universe and everything in it; who is striving to understand even a grain's worth of it before his time is up. Sagan was a self- professed agnostic and I think that comes out very clearly in this book. He explains the science well but then when he expands his though process, you can feel his writing borders on a sense of awe an reverence for the universe. Sagan's writing is powerful. Many times, I had to catch my breath and read a line again; the impact was huge. With the most simple of words, Sagan weaves magic. He makes us realise how inconsequential we are in the grand scheme of things while at the same time telling us that we are all extraordinary, because we are all made of stars. Sagan has tried to resolve scientific concepts and human kind's awe for the universe in this book. He touches on everything from evolution, superstition, Kepler, relativity, planets, ancient scientists, nuclear war and the cosmos. He also handles concepts like religion, books, belief, intolerance and what not. Recommended reading for everyone. I read the e-version of the book, but I'm getting my hands on a hardbound version and its going on my bookshelf, and into the hands of my son as soon as he's old enough to understand at least parts of this. Absolutely breathtaking!!

The Cosmos is everything that was, that is and that will ever be. Carl Sagan takes us through this exquisite journey starting with the origins and evolution of life on earth, then about our endeavors to explore the inner solar system comprising of the venus and mars. He points out that just like the americas and india were unexplored centuries ago, when the only known land was europe, such is our current situation on the shores of the cosmic ocean- with lot of worlds to be explored yet. He opines that the next striking thing to dawn upon us will be the news of contact with an extra-terrestrial civilization and that he is eagerly awaiting for it. He also explains how he is humbled by the immensity of space and how worthless is our fight for little more space in this pitiable corner of the cosmos. He explains how man since the ancient times, was keen to know what those shiny little things were up above in the night sky, and also how knowing their cycles meant the difference between life and death for him. He praises the greek for their practical wisdom and contributions to astronomy. He also approves the indian mythological concept of cycles of creation and destruction. He also presents an alarming fact that once a civilization reaches a certain amount of scientific progress, it tends to destroy ourselves, and that it is an inevitability in our near future. In last few chapters he talks about travel to nearby stars. It was an exciting read. Those who are passionate about astronomy, our origins and man's explorations into space will really love it. Now that I have completed it, I am eagerly waiting for Christopher Nolan's Interstellar to get released!

It was truly an honour to read this book. I am so lucky to have been born after Carl Sagan, and to be born in a time when books can be published - more specifically, Carl Sagan's books. This book isn't just a favourite - it's a book I love.I don't really read non-fiction, so for people out there who don't either, this review is for you.Cosmos is a wonderful book that explores the origins of the universe and the origins of humanity at the same time. Carl Sagan is a wonderful writer who offers the reader a comprehensive understanding of the foundations of our universe, and the beginning of scientific thought. He reflects on the past of human beings, introduces us to theories about astronomy, and gives us hope for the future. Carl Sagan's words ignite the "starstuff" within you - truly.This book is a great read if you love learning. And if you don't, this book will make you love learning, and love reading, because Carl Sagan is a wonderful writer. He truly understands and appreciates the power of language, and it is evident in his writing. In some ways, he bares his thoughts to the reader - which is why you fall in love with distant galaxies and astronomy - because you can't help but see the universe through his eyes.And if you're not really interested in space, then that's okay. Because this book is also about the origins of humanity. Not just rational thought or science, but a lot of the milestones that made us who we are today. This book is both a museum of the universe and of the Earth - and I recommend it to lovers of reading, knowledge, science, history, or just anybody with a vested interest in humanity and its future.

I have hired this book from the local Astronomy Society library shelves, but also bought the full DVD series of what must be some of the finest t.v. ever made. So 30 years on I'm firstly watching one of the hour long programmes and then reading the relevant chapter in the book. I already know this is 5 star.Published in 1980 and based on Sagan's epic 13 part t.v. series, Cosmos is a remarkable journey. A trip for the mind and a meditation for the soul. Our travels into the Cosmos takes us through human history, from the Egyptian, Chinese and Greek early sciences into the European Enlightenment (or re-discovery). On to the 4 billion year formation of Hydrogen molecules into complex DNA, then off into space for a tour of the solar system. Sagan includes stops off the spaceship to hit the reader with Biology, or Ecology, or domesday scenarios of nuclear destruction. Then we're off to the stars again. The t.v. series is so good I'm only up to part 7, and each part I've watched twice. Carl Sagan is sadly missed. What this publication would have been with the images of Hubble! The book makes do with many fine paintings of solar and deep space subjects, but you feel Carl would have loved Hubble.Finally in the authors own words: The surface of the Earth is the shore of the cosmic ocean. From it we have learned most of what we know. Recently, we have waded a little out to sea, enough to dampen our toes or, at most, wet our ankles. The water seems inviting. The ocean calls. Some part of our being knows this is from where we came. We long to return.

This took a long time to get through, partly because it was so tempting to read it with Sagan's measured, stately narration as in the outstanding TV series. I also dragged my heels in the sections that most showed their age, such as the lengthy descriptions of the then-nascent Mars missions, the unknown cause of the extinction of the dinosaurs, and the calculation of sum totals of a species' information in terms of bits of data (he kindly defines for us what a bit is).I found myself wishing he hadn't passed away 15 years ago, as his voice is at once so rational and knowledgeable and so emotionally compelling that perhaps he is our species' best hope for sanity and peaceful cooperation--our best hope for a continuing future. Then again, precisely *because* he is able to channel his vision and understanding of the big picture to anyone who will stop to consider our place in the cosmos, his arguments will long outlive the both of us. This is ultimately the most powerful anti-war document I can imagine, written in the long shadow of nuclear proliferation. Even as he is clearly desperate for humanity to wake up to its possibilities, he delivers his message through such an unending awe for life on Earth that he is at once revered scientist and star-struck child--and he invites us to join him in both roles.I still prefer the raw power of the PBS series over the book (yes, even as the graphics have long since crossed over into the realm of cheese), but any devotee of the TV show would appreciate the chance to peruse the book at leisure.

Cosmos is a nonfiction book written by the award winning astronomer Carl Sagen, and it is considered to be a classic of astronomy. It covers many topics related to astronomy, from the beginning of the universe to the possibilities of life on other planets to the future of the human race in space, all of them are covered in detail and in easy to understand language.  The book, which was originally written in conjunction with the Cosmos TV series, is a very interesting journey into the world of astronomy, with brief descriptions of much of the contents so as to fit more into the book, essentially filling all the basics of astronomy and all studies related to it into one book. The book also makes an interesting use of a combination of religious ideas and metaphors into the normally squarely scientific area of astronomy. While I personally feel that this is not a good scientific principal, I can certainly see how it would lead to not only a better understanding but also an increased interest and acceptance of some of the ideas elsewhere in the book, along with the ones being discussed. I liked this book, especially how it condensed many different areas of astronomy and science in general into the one book, but still making it all fit and feel like one book. I did, however, feel that the book did not have a very clear layout of the chapters, and therefor felt slightly disorganized. I would recommend this book to anyone at all interested in almost any branch of science, especially astronomy.

In the life of a human being 30 years might seem as a lot of time, but compared to 30 years for modern science, it seems less than minuscule. A lot has happened since Cosmos was written and some of the theories expressed there are dated, some seemingly unanswerable questions have been answered and there are plenty of new pages of history to discover.That being said, I never approached reading Cosmos as a science book and I believe that nobody should. While it still contains some deal of dry science data (how many bits it was again, Mr. Sagan?), most of which is valid today as well, it is primary as popular-scientific book that succeeds more at being an intricate mixture of hard sciences - physics, chemistry, astronomy, biology - and different sub-types of philosophy, most notably metaphysics and cosmology with a great deal of history of science sprinkled on top for added value.As in most pop-sci books, the language is more than pleasant and allows the book to be read with ease, any science bits are described as simplified as possible and just like the TV-Series, Cosmos probably is the most quotable book I've encountered up to date.If I did not mind encroaching on people too much and I lived in a country where English was more widely spoken and I was more fanatical about science, I might go around preaching from it. Come to think of it, I might anyhow just for the laughs of it.

My mother gave this book to me when I was in the 1st grade and it was one of the biggest eye openers of my childhood. Even though at the time I didn't understand most of the scientific jargon, my fascination with outer space and the planets drew me in and I was hooked. By the 3rd grade I was giving oral reports on black holes and the fabric of space-time and boring the hell out of my friends with my nonstop space rants. I've re-read it at least 6 different times since then as well as numerous other books by Steven Hawking and Kirshner and I can honestly say this is the greatest book about outer space/civilization/technology that I have ever read. The speculative fiction/non-fiction elements blend together perfectly and there is a never ending source of independence to what you can get out of this book. This book is a look at the big picture, the universe. Written by debatably the smartest astrophysicist of all time, Carl Sagan understood the universe possibly more than any human being who has ever lived. This book is the "Space Bible". Don't watch the series until you have read the book, and make sure it's the coffee table edition. The tiny paperback edition doesn't do justice to the amazing paintings. Every home in the world should have a copy.

This book had been on my list for a while and in my possession even longer. I decided it would get bumped up to "on-deck" when I saw a stranger holding it and overheard her commenting to a friend: "I read Cosmos at least 1 time a year."Having read Cosmos, I won't read it once a year, but I will make an effort to re-read the book while I'm still a young adult and hopefully read it again at a later date beyond that. The material in this book is awe inspiring and Carl Sagan has a real gift for eloquence and for communicating complex ideas effectively. Admittedly, some of the info is just a bit too hard to grasp (the size of the Universe), and other info is simply recondite mainly b/c it's outside the realm of our experience (relativity)... but the book is still definately worth a go. In a single sentence, this is a balm in book form for an existential crisis. I was feeling lost and confused in this painful universe and searching for something on the order of magnitude of religion to believe in, but religion has always seemed inadequate. If you've ever felt yourself moved or compelled by science, this is it.My first introduction to Carl Sagan's Cosmos was by my 8th grade science teacher, who wrote the chemical equations for photosynthesis and cellular respiration on the blackboard, one above the other, and asked us to stare at it until we had realized the beauty of this wonderous cycle that nature had set up. He then read the passage to us (the one about the mouth-to-stoma resuscitation), and that was my first glimpse of Sagan's ability to convey profound observations about the beauty of the universe in such simple and elegant terms.I grabbed this off a used bookstore shelf in search of something to believe in, and devoured it in one night. Felt a little better about my existence, and that of our world, afterwards. Absolutely incredible.

Carl Sagan's beautiful words transform you to outside the earth, into the cosmos and lets you appreciate the grandeur of the universe. Read the book to appreciate the Universe and Nature and the fact that you are the result of innumerable, highly unlikely things occurring at the right place and the right time.

This was truly a mind-expanding and thought-provoking book. Made me ponder over a lot of things. Carl Sagan takes you on a journey to the end of universe, he makes you think about the origin of our species, about the origin of our planet and what might our species do in the future. This book has made me look at things from a different perspective. This book has made me realise that our planet is not such a bad place after all. We are so lucky to be part of this rare planet and we must do everything to savour it. The world, the people , everything that you see around yourself is made from the elements that created the universe- the cosmos. To quote from the book : The cosmos may be densely populated with intelligent beings. But the Darwinian lesson is clear: There will be no humans elsewhere. Only here. Only on this small planet. We are a rare as well as an endangered species. Every one of us is, in the cosmic perspective, precious. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another.

I found Cosmos to be an excellent, accessible introduction to a wide range of scientific discoveries from the past few centuries. I also appreciated how, despite the book's Western bent, Sagan incorporated pre-scientific ideas from several non-European cultures, to show how scientific discoveries are made in parallel.That said, I saw this book as more history than science — a history of science, yes, but still history. The benefit to this is that, although the book was published nearly 40 years ago, much of it still remains relevant; the downside to this is that it is not very in-depth, and the title felt misleading. Another downside, in my opinion, is that its philosophical musings were a bit tedious, but that's my personal taste.I would highly recommend this book for any non-STEM major friends that want to jump into scientific nonfiction but don't know where to start; otherwise, I would recommend Welcome to the Universe by Neil deGrasse Tyson for those looking for a more in-depth intro to astrophysics.

I picked up this book at the University of Chicago bookstore, and it is undoubtedly the best $20 that I have ever spent. Carl Sagan is not only a scientist, but a true humanitarian. His brilliant writing and compassionate narrative instilled in me a sense of awe and respect for science, the cosmos, and life. Every one of us is made of the elements from the stars, which are everywhere in the cosmos, but each human being is also the only instance of themself in the entire universe. Billions of billions of billions of atoms formed the cosmos, and the cosmos made the earth, and the earth made life, and humans. On a cosmic scale, warfare and animosity towards other members of our own species seem so trivial, yet they threaten the destruction of life that came from millions of years of painstaking evolution. In the cosmos, If we do not speak for earth, then no one will. And all of us together speak for earth. Seeing things from a cosmic perspective is humbling. I encourage you to go on a cosmic voyage with Carl Sagan, and set sail for the stars.

This is not just a sit-down-and-read-straight-through kind of book. It's more of a coffee table book, but that label tends to belittle its contents. This is a hugely eye-opening, all-encompassing coverage of the collective universe as experienced by the human race so far.The book's general theme, as with the TV series upon which it is based, is the uniqueness of human life in the midst of so much astrophysical indifference and chaos. The bulk of the text provides scientific facts about space, species, evolution, energy, motion, matter, and accompanying insight about the ramifications of said facts. But there seems to be an overarching message of existentialism - humanity holding its own fate in its hands. It encourages scientific inquiry and promotes a message of developing technology further for the purpose of educating ourselves further as living residents of a vast, mysterious universe, and how we might continue to survive as a species in such a volatile environment.

This should be required reading in schools. Its subject matter is focused on science but the telling of the story is so rich and embedded with historical and social commentary that makes it a gripping read and drives the pace along, despite being about something as lofty and uncommon in the average person's lives as astronomy. Carl Sagan makes astronomy and the sciences wholly approachable, while also contagiously spreading the nearly holy reverence he has for the cosmos, and rightly so. It reads like poetic literature, religious text, scientific briefing, philosophical tome, and a history of all existence. I was seriously blown away. It is hard to read this book and look at anything around us without a sense of connectedness and awe that we happen to exist as this bizarre collection of basic elements, each made distinct by electric and nuclear forces and an unfathomably long period of time, and are able to gather here and be able to read this book.

So I finished this last night/super early this morning (1 am) and am still slightly in awe. I've always enjoyed learning about space and the universe, but never really had the mathematical chops to make it into a real hobby. This book changed all that, and within an explanation of the history of astronomy, made it into a much more accessible area of study. I'm certainly not going to become an astronomer, but this book was eye-opening simply for how such complex concepts were re-written so as to be more easily understood. Science and scientists cannot remain in an ivory tower, and this book represents a concerted effort to remove that and make astronomy open to many. But what mostly struck me was the way that Dr. Sagan contextualized humans and their conflicts within the universe. He draws a picture of humans as simply an evolution of the cosmos, that we as a species are something both far lesser and far greater than how we view ourselves.

This has been one of the most acclaimed books of the recent past and with good reason. I was pleasantly surprised at how relevant this book still is after decades of publication. Carl Sagan to be honest I'll write it in a very brief way ,allow me to tell that this book and the heavy details invaded every atom or more precisely every quark of my body Thank you very much for this treasure !! _______________________We have held the peculiar notion that a person or society that is a little different from us, whoever we are, is somehow strange or bizarre, to be distrusted or loathed. Most non-fiction science books related to the physical sciences suffer mostly from an overzealous attempt at exposing the "new science", the most recent findings and theories. This is a double-edged sword. They can be good reads, and even contextually interesting -being able to see what we "believed" to be true science years ago. But there's a drawback in this approach. The books might be marvelously written, but they're usually doomed to become outdated or even obsolete as the years pass. Newer findings contradicting and questioning the old theories espoused in these works of literature. But Sagan avoids this doomed fate while even stating some outdated scientific arguments that require obvious updating. This book remains a fascinating work, regardless of this small shortcoming, because it takes a different approach. This book is about humanity, our origin, our collective quest for science, and what our place is among the Cosmos. In this approach, Sagan crafted a timeless piece of non-fiction science literature which stands the test of time. Curiosity feeds the hearth of humankind's capacity for doing research and accumulating knowledge. Humbling, exalting, humanistic, and naturalistic; transcending nationalities, ethnicities, and even species in some ways. Sagan attempts to ground humanity in an evolutionary cosmic view, trying to show us how minuscule we are while simultaneously showing how interrelated we are to everything else -in the planet and in the universe-, and how ingenious and incredible we can be. We're simple starstuff capable of understanding how small we are in this universe, and that's amazing. For Sagan, we should be humbled by the knowledge that billions of years of physical, chemical and biological processes have resulted in us, a bipedal race of apes capable of looking beyond our planet to our true origins in the Cosmos: the complex processes that gave rise to our Universe, our galaxy, our solar system, our planet, and us.Even so, Sagan attempts to not idealize our history too much, recognizing our flaws time and again throughout the pages. Our political, economic, and ideological shortcomings that have resulted in countless cases of human atrocities. He urges us to learn from these to break the wheel of repetition that limits humanity from ushering in a better era, not allowing us to improve ourselves as a species. Sagan is quick to judge the atrocities of our ancestors (slavery, imperialism, fascism, Stalinism, racism, sexism, etc.), even going so far as to argue for a complete reformulation of our society. He favors a careful reevaluation of our society, and the dissolution of our current status quo (the preservation of which, he warns us, will only assure our inevitable self-destruction as a species). But Sagan also deeply valued our capacity for creating knowledge, and the beautiful, unifying similarities that can be observed throughout our history as a species, across different eras and civilizations. Similarities that can be observed in their respective quests for natural truth, achieving independent discoveries and arriving at similar conclusions, all of this achieved by people separated across centuries in time, across different cultures and ethnicities, and across continents separated from each other by miles of water. Humanity can do great things and terrifying things, and it's what we choose to do that will dictate the future of our species.

If you've known me for more than a little while, you know that one of my great loves in this world is science. Even though I tend to get stymied by the math, and I probably couldn't call up all the right data from my head at the right time, it is the idea of science and the stories of science that truly interest me. Just the fact that we live in a universe where it is possible to know how things work, where we can devise a way to look at the whole of creation, from things so large that they defy imagination to things so small that they can barely be said to exist at all. Science is imagination put into practice against the universe, and as much fun as stories and myths are, as hope and prayers may be, science is the best, most reliable way for us to come to grips with the Cosmos.It is to Carl Sagan that I owe this love of what humans have done with ourselves.When I was a kid, my father had a copy of Cosmos, and, since I was but a child, I never really read it. I tended more to flip through it for the interesting pictures - the speculative Jovian life forms on pages 42 and 43, the Viking photos of Mars in chapter 5, the gorgeous paintings of the views from other worlds around other stars, the photos of nebulae and galaxies, all of these things fascinated me, and if I had been a bit more patient I would have found out about them. But I was a kid, so that can be excused. What the book did for me was to open my mind to a universe of possibilities that were all within our reach, or at least would be someday.As I got older, I saw the TV miniseries of the same name on PBS. Now the pictures that I had lingered over in the book were right before me, accompanied by Sagan's soothing baritone. His ship of the imagination somehow managed to take us unfathomable distances from our home and bring us back again. He talked to his viewers like we were intelligent adults, fully capable of understanding and appreciating the vast scope of scientific discovery rather than a bunch of attention-deficit teenagers who couldn't be trusted to keep watching without a jump-cut every ten seconds. Carl Sagan believed, despite the occasional evidence to the contrary, that human beings were capable of overcoming our barbaric pasts and forging a bright new future together in the stars.The purpose of Cosmos, both the book and the TV show, was to educate. It was, as Sagan put it, "to engage the heart as well as the mind," perhaps to help shed the image of science as a cold and passionless pursuit. He wanted to show how science became what is is, from the ancient scientist/philosophers in Ionia and Alexandria all the way up to the engineers and astronauts working at NASA. It's all part of a long chain of knowledge that ties human history together and which engages one of our deepest desires: to know how the universe works.Each chapter focuses on a different theme of knowledge - from the way the planets form and what they're like to the nature of the furthest reaches of space. He starts with how Eratosthenes measured the world with just a shadow and some math, and how the ancient thinkers of Alexandria were asking the same questions about the nature of the Earth that we ask today. He follows the tortured path of Johannes Kepler in his quest to understand how the planets move, the arrogant brilliance of Newton as he completely redefined the clockwork of the cosmos, and the casual miracle that Einstein pulled off when he told us that not only are we not the center of the universe but that there is no center. Each great mind led to another.Unfortunately, each setback cost us what may be valuable time. For all his wonderment, he understood how petty and ignorant human beings could be. From the beginning, and at various points in the book, he reminds us of the millennium we lost with the destruction and corruption of the ancient thinkers of the Mediterranean. As far as we can tell, the men and women who made their home in Alexandria were investigating questions and scientific problems that would have changed the way we understand the world. If the library hadn't been burned down, if religious terror hadn't murdered scientific insight, who knows where we would be today? It's impossible to know, but it's tempting to think that we might have been well on our way to the stars by now.The latter chapters underscore that theme pretty heavily, reminding us over and over again that we have one world, and only one world. Not only does Sagan fear that we could obliterate ourselves with the nuclear weapons we love and fear so much, but he also fears that self-annihilation may be a natural outcome to any intelligent civilization. Our search for intelligent life on other worlds may be fruitless, because they might be just as self-destructive as we are.But we don't know. We can't know, at least not yet. Our understanding of the universe is still not clear enough, our technology is still not good enough, and perhaps it never will be. But for all our stumbles and failures, Sagan wants us to remember and understand just how much humanity is capable of, and how good we could be if we really put our minds to it. And in that sense, there is a lot of value to reading it now, thirty years after it was published.While we have not eliminated nuclear weapons, we have made great strides towards controlling them and reducing their numbers. The hopes that Sagan had for future space exploration - Mars rovers, a probe to Titan, contact with comets - have all been made real, and with outstanding results. We know that the dinosaurs were wiped out by a meteor impact - something that Sagan is clearly unsure of at the time of writing. We have mapped the human genome and developed personal computers that have revolutionized the way we explore space. With the internet, any person on earth can catalog galaxies or explore the moon, there have been advances in nanotechnology and materials and bioengineering and evolution that would have made even Sagan's eyes pop.Despite all our flaws, we continue to advance. We continue to build knowledge upon knowledge and to further our understanding of how the universe works. Maybe we will one day leave this planet ourselves, perhaps just for a visit or perhaps to start a new world. Maybe if we persist in our quest to comprehend the world we live in, to shut out the howling and screaming of the voices of unreason, we can make the world a better place for generations to come. In the great argument that is raging these days between the rationalists and the believers, the faithful and the atheists, it has become fashionable to try and shout the other side down. To adopt a position that excludes compromise and promises only defeat for one side or another. Sagan never would have wanted that, and I think he hit upon a solution that needs to be revisited.Rather than try to turn people to science through cold logic or heated words, through derision and coercion and fear, do as Sagan did: win them over with wonder. The cosmos is too big, and there is too much to know to waste our time with petty arguments and pointless feuds. If you want people to appreciate science, turn to people like Sagan, or Neil deGrasse Tyson, or Phil Plait, or Michio Kaku, or Bill Nye, or Adam Savage,[1] people whose enthusiasm and love of science will instill people with wonder, one person at a time. And it is in that way that we will go furthest towards ensuring humanity's place among the stars.----------------------------------------------------"Every one of us is precious in the cosmic perspective. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another."- Carl Sagan, Cosmos[1] In the interest of fairness, I tried to come up with female scientists who were at the forefront of popularizing science with the public. I drew a blank. If you know some, please let me know so I can put them on the list....

Cosmos Phenomenal book. This is like seeing a star athlete a year or two before his peak. You’re getting to see his greatness but you know he is about to explode soon. This is Sagan on the verge of his greatness. He is hitting on so many topics, provoking the human imagination, tantalizing the mind, and curating curiosity of the universe. I normally read books at 1.25 speed and read one book at a time but I wanted to savior Sagan. I read at normal speed and listened in between reading other books. This is a wonderful adventure. Sagan talks about the origins of the universe, I have rarely heard him talk about black holes but he briefly does in this book. Theoretical physics was never his field of study but I wonder if he and Hawking had any interactions. Even just being two of the most famous scientists in the world. He talks about the creation of planets, the depths of the cosmos, the fragility of human existence, nuclear proliferation, galaxies, extraterrestrial life, and more. On planets: The planets in our solar system are wild. Mars is interesting because its close to us but the other planets have much more to offer. His discussions about Mercury, Venus, and Jupiter, are amazing. These planets are playgrounds for scientific discovery. When he was talking about Mars, he talked about the origins of life. I have long argued that science handcuffs itself with the requirements for life but Sagan has changed my mind. He dives in to chemistry and biology, showing that carbon, hydrogen, and other key elements are the building blocks for life. We are not just looking at our life but the elements that are must abundant in the universe and that form life. It is conceivable that life could be formed through aluminum and sulfur but it is highly unlikely. I learned in this section.His discussion of Jupiter is wild. Worth rereading.Sun/Stars: he has a whole section about stars and their origins. How the are born and die. It is very chemistry heavy. Suffice to say, our sun is rather small and ordinary. Everything comes from the sun. He uses the term ‘higher power’ to describe the sun and that it is acceptable to consider the sun a higher power. Chemistry/biology: I felt that this book had the most technical information about chemistry and biology. These are subjects that I struggle with. Sagan was dense but as usual fascinating with his talk about these fields. I really learned how the study of the universe is a shared field, it is not limited to astronomers. Chemists and biologists play a huge role in our understanding of the universe. Gravity and light have their own rules but much of the universe is governed by the rules and laws of chemistry and biology. These are fields that are not given enough attention.Galaxies: This is where he gets into numbers, time, and size. This is where my head really started to spin. The sheer size of the universe and what it contains is hard to comprehend. ‘There are more stars in the universe than there are grains of sand on all the beaches on earth.’ What the fuck!? We are nothing.He talks about pulsars, star clusters, different kinds of galaxies, the rotation of galaxies, the size of galaxies, galaxies colliding, and more. I want to write more but even thinking about it all I can say is ‘dude, dude, dude, the fucking universe’.A point that caught me ‘the distance between galaxies is often two million light years.’The fact that our galaxy rotates. I am gonna stop writing and just say, ‘read Carl Sagan.’Extraterrestrial life: a popular topic and fascination of Sagan’s. I believe that Sagan was a man that wanted nothing more than to find some evidence of life outside of earth. Sadly he never found it. He breaks down the numbers of life, the Drake equation, the way we could communication (prime numbers and radio waves), the time it would take to send and receive messages (centuries), the time to search for an expand out in the galaxy to find life, the evolution of life and civilization, and more. This is a section near the end of the book and the section on nuclear war follows it. It is the brilliance and heart break of Sagan. He looks at the possibility for life, the possibility for science, understanding our fragility of human existence, he sees how powerful and beautiful humans are, he loves humans and loves science, always the optimist, but also a realist. He saw that we could be greater but recognized that we were causing our own extinction. That it is likely we will never become a space faring civilization because we would destroy ourselves first. It’s possible that this is the path of other civilizations or others avoided the obsession, ignorance, greed, and malice that we commit. Sagan was an optimist but in many ways he also thought that we were utterly doomed. My personal thoughts about extraterrestrial life: The universe is 13 billions years old and have trillions of stars in it. It is the height of arrogance to think that we are the only life and the height of ignorance to act as if we are not directly causing our own extinction.Nuclear war: Sagan advocated strongly for nuclear proliferation. Seeing nuclear weapons as an existential threat to humanity. His advocacy on this and other political, social, and environmental issues, is one of the reasons why I love him. The next book I will read is ‘A path where no man thought’. His book about nuclear weapons. I will write more about his thoughts when I finish that book. The last half hour is mind blowing. It puts into perspective everything that Sagan is saying. Our tiny place on a pale blue dot. We found food prints that are a million or more years old that belong to one of our ancestors and we put foot prints on the moon. ‘We have an obligation to survive. Our loyalty is to the specious and the planet. We owe it to the cosmos to survive.’This is Sagan at is best. This is the greatest science educator humans have been gifted. This book is a master at his finest. I implore you to read this book.
