Carl Sagan's Cosmos was genuinely enjoyable. It's filled with awe and wonder and hope and was uplifting and exactly what I needed. I considered reading The Sixth Extinction and decided against it once COVID-19 hit. Between the daily marathon press briefings and the talking heads on the news 24 hours a day and the impossibility of avoiding discussion of COVID-19 on social media, I believed The Sixth Extinction would exacerbate my depression. I needed something joyful in my reading life. Enter Cosmos.I listened to the audiobook narrated by LeVar Burton with a foreword by Neil deGrasse Tyson. I do so love LeVar Burton. Reading Rainbow was my childhood and sparked in me a love of reading.Sagan's language in Cosmos is beautiful. I liked the words he chose and the meandering flow of his writing. He writes intelligently about complex ideas, but I didn't feel like I was out of my depth. I felt like I understood the concepts in the book because Sagan's writing is so good, and I did learn a few things. The concepts in the book are imaginative without being silly and too over the top. I also enjoyed how the book translated to the TV show. I especially liked the following chapters:* Heaven and Hell - Not about the religious idea of Heaven and Hell but about the potential for heavenly and hellish worlds to exist in the universe* Blues for a Red Planet - About Mars*The Persistence of MemoryEven though Cosmos was written in 1980, it's not too noticeably outdated. Voyager 1 and 2 have both left the solar system and are traveling through interstellar space. We have put unmanned rovers on Mars, and both Spirit's and Opportunity's missions have ended while Curiosity continues its exploration. We have 3 billion more people on Earth. Cosmos didn't read at all like an old high school textbook. Sagan obviously held liberal views and said he was agnostic because, "An atheist is someone who is certain that God does not exist, someone who has compelling evidence against the existence of God. I know of no such compelling evidence." If these beliefs don't align at least somewhat with yours, then you may not like Cosmos.My only complaint - and it's a minor one about the audiobook specifically that didn't affect my rating of the book - is the narration is overacted and too staccato. I know Burton is passionate and was likely trying to create passion in the listener, but there are places where he sounds very William Shatner as Captain Kirk emphasizing words strangely. Burton sometimes sounds like he's out of breath. I would have liked to have the multiple narrators take turns reading chapters.

The good news is like how author later put it "humans have evolved to wonder, that understanding is a joy, that knowledge is prerequisite to survival. I believe our future depends on how well we know this Cosmos in which we float like a note of dust in the morning sky". Ah, the importance of continuous learning. As our mind evolved and developed, using both our right and left hemisphere of thinking and creating, we can venture into the unknown. Carl Sagan’s «Cosmos» is as inspiring and poignant today as when it was published. In it he shows us a way to the stars, from the very beginning of life itself until the distant future where our descendants travel the universe. He explores the history of our planet, of scientific thought and inquiry, the evolution of life, human brilliance and curiosity - but also the destructive parts of us that can end up destroying all of civilization.The book had the Cold War as a specter in the background, but yet it is as relevant today as when it was first published. Sagan shows how human intelligence and spirit can be used for good - or for bad. How compassion and hatred both exist in us, and how we can work together to prioritize one over the other. The same technology, he points out, can be used for warfare or galactic exploration. Humanity can travel to the stars for less than what we use on military spending in a year. But to manage it we need to work together. In 2020, as distrust, anti-scientific attitudes and displays of power amongst world leaders are once again evident, this book is as important as ever. If we recognize the signs we might be able to prevent the next burning of the “Library at Alexandria” and the descent into ignorance that would follow. An ignorance that could be the end of humanity.Sagan makes a case for nature, science, curiosity, love, companionship, free thought, demilitarization, cooperation, sexual freedom and human enterprise. He gives us hope that a better world is possible, if we can only stop our skirmishes and ask ourselves the question: who speaks for Earth? Who will stand for humanity? What will be left of us if we don’t manage to speak as one, to realize we all share this planet; that each one of us is a cosmic incredulity, a wonder, so insignificantly few in the grand scheme of things that we need to start preserving humanity as one? Everyone should read this book, feel inspired - and thereafter we should start doing what we can for the world of tomorrow. We can start, as Sagan puts it, by kissing our infants.

That’s here. That’s home. That’s us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every “superstar,” every “supreme leader,” every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there—on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.”“It pays to keep an open mind, but not so open your brains fall out.”“The brain is like a muscle. When it is in use we feel very good. Understanding is joyous.”“Somewhere, something incredible is waiting to be known.”“Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence.”“There are naive questions, tedious questions, ill-phrased questions, questions put after inadequate self-criticism. But every question is a cry to understand the world. There is no such thing as a dumb question.”

Most non-fiction science books related to the physical sciences suffer mostly from an overzealous attempt at exposing the "new science", the most recent findings and theories. This is a double-edged sword. They can be good reads, and even contextually interesting -being able to see what we "believed" to be true science years ago. But there's a drawback in this approach. The books might be marvelously written, but they're usually doomed to become outdated or even obsolete as the years pass. Newer findings contradicting and questioning the old theories espoused in these works of literature. But Sagan avoids this doomed fate while even stating some outdated scientific arguments that require obvious updating. This book remains a fascinating work, regardless of this small shortcoming, because it takes a different approach. This book is about humanity, our origin, our collective quest for science, and what our place is among the Cosmos. In this approach, Sagan crafted a timeless piece of non-fiction science literature which stands the test of time. Curiosity feeds the hearth of humankind's capacity for doing research and accumulating knowledge. Humbling, exalting, humanistic, and naturalistic; transcending nationalities, ethnicities, and even species in some ways. Sagan attempts to ground humanity in an evolutionary cosmic view, trying to show us how minuscule we are while simultaneously showing how interrelated we are to everything else -in the planet and in the universe-, and how ingenious and incredible we can be. We're simple starstuff capable of understanding how small we are in this universe, and that's amazing. For Sagan, we should be humbled by the knowledge that billions of years of physical, chemical and biological processes have resulted in us, a bipedal race of apes capable of looking beyond our planet to our true origins in the Cosmos: the complex processes that gave rise to our Universe, our galaxy, our solar system, our planet, and us.Even so, Sagan attempts to not idealize our history too much, recognizing our flaws time and again throughout the pages. Our political, economic, and ideological shortcomings that have resulted in countless cases of human atrocities. He urges us to learn from these to break the wheel of repetition that limits humanity from ushering in a better era, not allowing us to improve ourselves as a species. Sagan is quick to judge the atrocities of our ancestors (slavery, imperialism, fascism, Stalinism, racism, sexism, etc.), even going so far as to argue for a complete reformulation of our society. He favors a careful reevaluation of our society, and the dissolution of our current status quo (the preservation of which, he warns us, will only assure our inevitable self-destruction as a species). But Sagan also deeply valued our capacity for creating knowledge, and the beautiful, unifying similarities that can be observed throughout our history as a species, across different eras and civilizations. Similarities that can be observed in their respective quests for natural truth, achieving independent discoveries and arriving at similar conclusions, all of this achieved by people separated across centuries in time, across different cultures and ethnicities, and across continents separated from each other by miles of water. Humanity can do great things and terrifying things, and it's what we choose to do that will dictate the future of our species.

If you've known me for more than a little while, you know that one of my great loves in this world is science. Even though I tend to get stymied by the math, and I probably couldn't call up all the right data from my head at the right time, it is the idea of science and the stories of science that truly interest me. Just the fact that we live in a universe where it is possible to know how things work, where we can devise a way to look at the whole of creation, from things so large that they defy imagination to things so small that they can barely be said to exist at all. Science is imagination put into practice against the universe, and as much fun as stories and myths are, as hope and prayers may be, science is the best, most reliable way for us to come to grips with the Cosmos.It is to Carl Sagan that I owe this love of what humans have done with ourselves.When I was a kid, my father had a copy of Cosmos, and, since I was but a child, I never really read it. I tended more to flip through it for the interesting pictures - the speculative Jovian life forms on pages 42 and 43, the Viking photos of Mars in chapter 5, the gorgeous paintings of the views from other worlds around other stars, the photos of nebulae and galaxies, all of these things fascinated me, and if I had been a bit more patient I would have found out about them. But I was a kid, so that can be excused. What the book did for me was to open my mind to a universe of possibilities that were all within our reach, or at least would be someday.As I got older, I saw the TV miniseries of the same name on PBS. Now the pictures that I had lingered over in the book were right before me, accompanied by Sagan's soothing baritone. His ship of the imagination somehow managed to take us unfathomable distances from our home and bring us back again. He talked to his viewers like we were intelligent adults, fully capable of understanding and appreciating the vast scope of scientific discovery rather than a bunch of attention-deficit teenagers who couldn't be trusted to keep watching without a jump-cut every ten seconds. Carl Sagan believed, despite the occasional evidence to the contrary, that human beings were capable of overcoming our barbaric pasts and forging a bright new future together in the stars.The purpose of Cosmos, both the book and the TV show, was to educate. It was, as Sagan put it, "to engage the heart as well as the mind," perhaps to help shed the image of science as a cold and passionless pursuit. He wanted to show how science became what is is, from the ancient scientist/philosophers in Ionia and Alexandria all the way up to the engineers and astronauts working at NASA. It's all part of a long chain of knowledge that ties human history together and which engages one of our deepest desires: to know how the universe works.Each chapter focuses on a different theme of knowledge - from the way the planets form and what they're like to the nature of the furthest reaches of space. He starts with how Eratosthenes measured the world with just a shadow and some math, and how the ancient thinkers of Alexandria were asking the same questions about the nature of the Earth that we ask today. He follows the tortured path of Johannes Kepler in his quest to understand how the planets move, the arrogant brilliance of Newton as he completely redefined the clockwork of the cosmos, and the casual miracle that Einstein pulled off when he told us that not only are we not the center of the universe but that there is no center. Each great mind led to another.Unfortunately, each setback cost us what may be valuable time. For all his wonderment, he understood how petty and ignorant human beings could be. From the beginning, and at various points in the book, he reminds us of the millennium we lost with the destruction and corruption of the ancient thinkers of the Mediterranean. As far as we can tell, the men and women who made their home in Alexandria were investigating questions and scientific problems that would have changed the way we understand the world. If the library hadn't been burned down, if religious terror hadn't murdered scientific insight, who knows where we would be today? It's impossible to know, but it's tempting to think that we might have been well on our way to the stars by now.The latter chapters underscore that theme pretty heavily, reminding us over and over again that we have one world, and only one world. Not only does Sagan fear that we could obliterate ourselves with the nuclear weapons we love and fear so much, but he also fears that self-annihilation may be a natural outcome to any intelligent civilization. Our search for intelligent life on other worlds may be fruitless, because they might be just as self-destructive as we are.But we don't know. We can't know, at least not yet. Our understanding of the universe is still not clear enough, our technology is still not good enough, and perhaps it never will be. But for all our stumbles and failures, Sagan wants us to remember and understand just how much humanity is capable of, and how good we could be if we really put our minds to it. And in that sense, there is a lot of value to reading it now, thirty years after it was published.While we have not eliminated nuclear weapons, we have made great strides towards controlling them and reducing their numbers. The hopes that Sagan had for future space exploration - Mars rovers, a probe to Titan, contact with comets - have all been made real, and with outstanding results. We know that the dinosaurs were wiped out by a meteor impact - something that Sagan is clearly unsure of at the time of writing. We have mapped the human genome and developed personal computers that have revolutionized the way we explore space. With the internet, any person on earth can catalog galaxies or explore the moon, there have been advances in nanotechnology and materials and bioengineering and evolution that would have made even Sagan's eyes pop.Despite all our flaws, we continue to advance. We continue to build knowledge upon knowledge and to further our understanding of how the universe works. Maybe we will one day leave this planet ourselves, perhaps just for a visit or perhaps to start a new world. Maybe if we persist in our quest to comprehend the world we live in, to shut out the howling and screaming of the voices of unreason, we can make the world a better place for generations to come. In the great argument that is raging these days between the rationalists and the believers, the faithful and the atheists, it has become fashionable to try and shout the other side down. To adopt a position that excludes compromise and promises only defeat for one side or another. Sagan never would have wanted that, and I think he hit upon a solution that needs to be revisited.Rather than try to turn people to science through cold logic or heated words, through derision and coercion and fear, do as Sagan did: win them over with wonder. The cosmos is too big, and there is too much to know to waste our time with petty arguments and pointless feuds. If you want people to appreciate science, turn to people like Sagan, or Neil deGrasse Tyson, or Phil Plait, or Michio Kaku, or Bill Nye, or Adam Savage,[1] people whose enthusiasm and love of science will instill people with wonder, one person at a time. And it is in that way that we will go furthest towards ensuring humanity's place among the stars.----------------------------------------------------"Every one of us is precious in the cosmic perspective. If a human disagrees with you, let him live. In a hundred billion galaxies, you will not find another."- Carl Sagan, Cosmos[1] In the interest of fairness, I tried to come up with female scientists who were at the forefront of popularizing science with the public. I drew a blank. If you know some, please let me know so I can put them on the list....

Cosmos Phenomenal book. This is like seeing a star athlete a year or two before his peak. You’re getting to see his greatness but you know he is about to explode soon. This is Sagan on the verge of his greatness. He is hitting on so many topics, provoking the human imagination, tantalizing the mind, and curating curiosity of the universe. I normally read books at 1.25 speed and read one book at a time but I wanted to savior Sagan. I read at normal speed and listened in between reading other books. This is a wonderful adventure. Sagan talks about the origins of the universe, I have rarely heard him talk about black holes but he briefly does in this book. Theoretical physics was never his field of study but I wonder if he and Hawking had any interactions. Even just being two of the most famous scientists in the world. He talks about the creation of planets, the depths of the cosmos, the fragility of human existence, nuclear proliferation, galaxies, extraterrestrial life, and more. On planets: The planets in our solar system are wild. Mars is interesting because its close to us but the other planets have much more to offer. His discussions about Mercury, Venus, and Jupiter, are amazing. These planets are playgrounds for scientific discovery. When he was talking about Mars, he talked about the origins of life. I have long argued that science handcuffs itself with the requirements for life but Sagan has changed my mind. He dives in to chemistry and biology, showing that carbon, hydrogen, and other key elements are the building blocks for life. We are not just looking at our life but the elements that are must abundant in the universe and that form life. It is conceivable that life could be formed through aluminum and sulfur but it is highly unlikely. I learned in this section.His discussion of Jupiter is wild. Worth rereading.Sun/Stars: he has a whole section about stars and their origins. How the are born and die. It is very chemistry heavy. Suffice to say, our sun is rather small and ordinary. Everything comes from the sun. He uses the term ‘higher power’ to describe the sun and that it is acceptable to consider the sun a higher power. Chemistry/biology: I felt that this book had the most technical information about chemistry and biology. These are subjects that I struggle with. Sagan was dense but as usual fascinating with his talk about these fields. I really learned how the study of the universe is a shared field, it is not limited to astronomers. Chemists and biologists play a huge role in our understanding of the universe. Gravity and light have their own rules but much of the universe is governed by the rules and laws of chemistry and biology. These are fields that are not given enough attention.Galaxies: This is where he gets into numbers, time, and size. This is where my head really started to spin. The sheer size of the universe and what it contains is hard to comprehend. ‘There are more stars in the universe than there are grains of sand on all the beaches on earth.’ What the fuck!? We are nothing.He talks about pulsars, star clusters, different kinds of galaxies, the rotation of galaxies, the size of galaxies, galaxies colliding, and more. I want to write more but even thinking about it all I can say is ‘dude, dude, dude, the fucking universe’.A point that caught me ‘the distance between galaxies is often two million light years.’The fact that our galaxy rotates. I am gonna stop writing and just say, ‘read Carl Sagan.’Extraterrestrial life: a popular topic and fascination of Sagan’s. I believe that Sagan was a man that wanted nothing more than to find some evidence of life outside of earth. Sadly he never found it. He breaks down the numbers of life, the Drake equation, the way we could communication (prime numbers and radio waves), the time it would take to send and receive messages (centuries), the time to search for an expand out in the galaxy to find life, the evolution of life and civilization, and more. This is a section near the end of the book and the section on nuclear war follows it. It is the brilliance and heart break of Sagan. He looks at the possibility for life, the possibility for science, understanding our fragility of human existence, he sees how powerful and beautiful humans are, he loves humans and loves science, always the optimist, but also a realist. He saw that we could be greater but recognized that we were causing our own extinction. That it is likely we will never become a space faring civilization because we would destroy ourselves first. It’s possible that this is the path of other civilizations or others avoided the obsession, ignorance, greed, and malice that we commit. Sagan was an optimist but in many ways he also thought that we were utterly doomed. My personal thoughts about extraterrestrial life: The universe is 13 billions years old and have trillions of stars in it. It is the height of arrogance to think that we are the only life and the height of ignorance to act as if we are not directly causing our own extinction.Nuclear war: Sagan advocated strongly for nuclear proliferation. Seeing nuclear weapons as an existential threat to humanity. His advocacy on this and other political, social, and environmental issues, is one of the reasons why I love him. The next book I will read is ‘A path where no man thought’. His book about nuclear weapons. I will write more about his thoughts when I finish that book. The last half hour is mind blowing. It puts into perspective everything that Sagan is saying. Our tiny place on a pale blue dot. We found food prints that are a million or more years old that belong to one of our ancestors and we put foot prints on the moon. ‘We have an obligation to survive. Our loyalty is to the specious and the planet. We owe it to the cosmos to survive.’This is Sagan at is best. This is the greatest science educator humans have been gifted. This book is a master at his finest. I implore you to read this book. Quotes: ‘no about of intellect can stop you from being dead wrong’‘We are star stuff’‘There are so many examples of humans misuse of the earth. We should leave mars to the martians’‘Are we willing to tolerate ignorance and complacency on matters that effect the earth. Or will we think on longer time scales.’‘Possible that civilizations succumb to greed, ignorance, pollution, and nuclear war’‘Deterrence depends above all on psychological criteria, for purposes of deterrence a bluff taken seriously, is more useful that serious threat interpreted as a bluff’ Henry Kissinger on Nuclear Deterrence Some text messages that I sent while reading the book: Fuuuuccccckkkkk. When you get the point that Sagan has talked about how big the universe is, the number of stars, and galaxies, then the insanity of the circumstances for life to exist, then he talks about extraterrestrial life and you hear his fascination with it but he says that maybe civilizations succumb to ignorance, pollution, nuclear war, etc.Its such a ‘Carl Sagan, Jesus fucking Christ! The worm hole that you send me down. The gratitude for life, the terror of our world, the possibility of life out there, the loneliness of the universe, the beauty of science, the power of love. You make me feel so many things.’The universe is 13 billions years old and have trillions of stars in it. It is the height of arrogance to think that we are the only life and the height of ignorance to act as if we are not directly causing our own extinction.

Carl Sagan's Cosmos was genuinely enjoyable. It's filled with awe and wonder and hope and was uplifting and exactly what I needed. I considered reading The Sixth Extinction and decided against it once COVID-19 hit. Between the daily marathon press briefings and the talking heads on the news 24 hours a day and the impossibility of avoiding discussion of COVID-19 on social media, I believed The Sixth Extinction would exacerbate my depression. I needed something joyful in my reading life. Enter Cosmos.I listened to the audiobook narrated by LeVar Burton with a foreword by Neil deGrasse Tyson. I do so love LeVar Burton. Reading Rainbow was my childhood and sparked in me a love of reading.Sagan's language in Cosmos is beautiful. I liked the words he chose and the meandering flow of his writing. He writes intelligently about complex ideas, but I didn't feel like I was out of my depth. I felt like I understood the concepts in the book because Sagan's writing is so good, and I did learn a few things. The concepts in the book are imaginative without being silly and too over the top. I also enjoyed how the book translated to the TV show. I especially liked the following chapters:* Heaven and Hell - Not about the religious idea of Heaven and Hell but about the potential for heavenly and hellish worlds to exist in the universe* Blues for a Red Planet - About Mars*The Persistence of MemoryEven though Cosmos was written in 1980, it's not too noticeably outdated. Voyager 1 and 2 have both left the solar system and are traveling through interstellar space. We have put unmanned rovers on Mars, and both Spirit's and Opportunity's missions have ended while Curiosity continues its exploration. We have 3 billion more people on Earth. Cosmos didn't read at all like an old high school textbook. Sagan obviously held liberal views and said he was agnostic because, "An atheist is someone who is certain that God does not exist, someone who has compelling evidence against the existence of God. I know of no such compelling evidence." If these beliefs don't align at least somewhat with yours, then you may not like Cosmos.My only complaint - and it's a minor one about the audiobook specifically that didn't affect my rating of the book - is the narration is overacted and too staccato. I know Burton is passionate and was likely trying to create passion in the listener, but there are places where he sounds very William Shatner as Captain Kirk emphasizing words strangely. Burton sometimes sounds like he's out of breath. I would have liked to have the multiple narrators take turns reading chapters.

A book that talks about the study of the stars, galaxy and our existence in all of this "space". It is interesting to read about Astronomy and science, the messages I picked up are about continuous learning and expansion. I believe our future depends on how well we know this Cosmos in which we float like a note of dust in the morning sky". Ah, the importance of continuous learning.
