Carl Sagan’s «Cosmos» is as inspiring and poignant today as when it was published. In it he shows us a way to the stars, from the very beginning of life itself until the distant future where our descendants travel the universe. He explores the history of our planet, of scientific thought and inquiry, the evolution of life, human brilliance and curiosity - but also the destructive parts of us that can end up destroying all of civilization.The book had the Cold War as a specter in the background, but yet it is as relevant today as when it was first published. Sagan shows how human intelligence and spirit can be used for good - or for bad. How compassion and hatred both exist in us, and how we can work together to prioritize one over the other. The same technology, he points out, can be used for warfare or galactic exploration. Humanity can travel to the stars for less than what we use on military spending in a year. But to manage it we need to work together. In 2020, as distrust, anti-scientific attitudes and displays of power amongst world leaders are once again evident, this book is as important as ever. If we recognize the signs we might be able to prevent the next burning of the “Library at Alexandria” and the descent into ignorance that would follow. An ignorance that could be the end of humanity.Sagan makes a case for nature, science, curiosity, love, companionship, free thought, demilitarization, cooperation, sexual freedom and human enterprise. He gives us hope that a better world is possible, if we can only stop our skirmishes and ask ourselves the question: who speaks for Earth? Who will stand for humanity? What will be left of us if we don’t manage to speak as one, to realize we all share this planet; that each one of us is a cosmic incredulity, a wonder, so insignificantly few in the grand scheme of things that we need to start preserving humanity as one? Everyone should read this book, feel inspired - and thereafter we should start doing what we can for the world of tomorrow. We can start, as Sagan puts it, by kissing our infants.

This was my first book by Sagan despite him being one of my childhood heroes, mainly due to the original Cosmos show and a few excerpts from his writings (the Pale Blue Dot passage, for example).Put simply, this book inspired me, and I don’t think I can honestly say that any other book has ever done so. Entertained, yes. Enlightened, of course. But never inspired. After three decades, I thought I was just the uninspired type. A book about science made me emotional. It made me think about humanity as a whole, about our amazing yet fragile progress on the long timeline of the universe, about our future. And more importantly, about my personal part in that future. Times are dark and we are seemingly more divided than we’ve been in many decades. Yet from where he sat only a few years ago, Carl Sagan had advice for us. He seemed to see the intrinsic problems facing us as a species, the flaws that might lead to our ultimate destruction, yes. But also—ever the inspiration—he saw a way forward. And maybe unsurprisingly, that way forward is simple and heartfelt. Simple, but perhaps not easy. There was so much in this book that hit home for me, or fascinated me, or gave me a sense of a kind of cosmic vertigo (in the best possible way). I found myself rereading passages on biology, chemistry, and physics in order to ensure I understood, out of a genuine interest in those subjects as presented by Sagan. With very few exceptions, interest in science hasn’t been my nature. I thought maybe I just didn’t have the brain for it. Turns out I didn’t have the right teacher. This kind of communication of science, this kind of inspiration... we need it more than ever. No one living now seems to be coming close, at least not anyone doing it on a large scale in popular media. I wish we still had someone like him, and like my little obsession with Joseph Campbell, I’m sure I’ll be reading a lot more of Sagan’s work.

Given the stunning eloquence with which Sagan writes Cosmos, I wish I were able to express my thoughts on the book in a more articulate way. Sadly, my writing caliber is not up to the challenge yet, so I’ll just start with “I loved this book.” Even though Sagan built his career in astronomy, he shows such respect towards all areas of knowledge, including the history --some of my favorite passages are ones where he discusses different stories of scientific discovery (never knew that Kepler and Tycho Brahe had such a troubled working relationship) or looks to the past for guidance on what to expect in the future (such as when he pointed to the meeting of Europeans and indigenous peoples in the Americas as a potential case study for future extraterrestrial contact). While all the material in the book was fascinating, one of my favorite chapters was “Blues for a Red Planet,” which chronicles the exploration of Mars by the Viking missions, as well as the challenges faced in the years of preparation leading up to launch. Even though the information related is several decades old, it deepened my respect for the ingenuity and expertise that went into the program and reminded me just how incredible it is that we’ve landed machines that were able to conduct experiments on the dirt of a planet hundreds of millions of miles away. I’m sure Sagan would be overjoyed to learn about the progress made on Mars rovers in the years since. Cosmos is absolutely wonderful in every sense and I’m sure it will continue to inspire curiosity in scientific endeavors and an appreciation for our place in the universe for many future generations of readers.

Personal ReviewI thought that this was a very good book. It was very informative. The author talked about astronomy through history and many of the big discoveries and how they changed through the years. The author made learning very fun for the common person. I thought that every chapter had something unique to offer and learn about.SummaryAt the beginning of each chapter the author starts it off with a historical quote dealing with that specific chapter. There is an introduction that gives an overview of the entire book and a very philosophical perspective on the subject. The author talks about some of the theories we have today and how they were influenced by discoveries thousands of years ago. He also explains the culture and government of the people that made these great discoveries. After this, the author shifts to talking about some of the modern day adventures of human space craft and how we are soon to visit other worlds. He talks about how science is sort of a religion and how it has changed the way the human race has thought over our thousands of years as a species. The author sort of goes back and forth to ancient and common times throughout the rest of the book.RecommendationI think that any scientist or anybody interested in physics would love this book. Just the fact that it is written by one of the most famous scientists of our time, Carl Sagan, is very appealing in itself. I also think that a high school physics student would be very well off if they read this book. The author does a very good job of explaining many very complex principles at the most elementary level possible.

I am genuinely upset that this isn't required reading for all 8th graders.I should've been offered this book! It should be free!I think we would have an even greater appreciation of science in society if this were more widely read. It's a fascinating look at the history of science and the development of ideas. What's more, Carl Sagan is a beautiful person, and it's very intimate to hear his childhood outlook and what sparked his curiosity. The speculations of how past events have turned out can be disheartening. Dr. Sagan defends the complexities of whale communication; how they can communicate thousands of kilometers apart, essentially having evolved a natural telephone system they've relied upon for centuries. He laments the disruptions human navies have caused by our wanton use of sonar and radio communications to the extent that whales are limited to communication of a few kilometers. There is also the then unknown effects of climate change and the recognition of the small progress we've had today.I thought this book would be far outdated, but I now believe it is timeless. Also, if Levar Burton had read all my textbooks to me, I would've had multiple PhD's in science by now.

This made my head asplode. "On another planet, with a different sequence of random processes to make hereditary diversity and a different environment to select particular combinations of genes, the chances of finding beings who are physically very similar to us is, I believe, near zero. The chances of finding another form of intelligence is not. Their brains may well have evolved from the inside out. They may have switching elements analogous to our neurons. But the neurons may be very different; perhaps superconductors that work at very low temperatures rather than organic devices that work at room temperature, in which case their speed of thought will be 10*7 times faster than ours. Or perhaps the equivalent of neurons elsewhere would not be in direct physical contact but in radio communication so that a single intelligent being could be distributed among many different organisms, or even many different planets, each with a part of the intelligence of the whole, each contributing by radio to an intelligence much greater than itself"

What a fascinating book! And so eloquently written. Carl Sagan has a knack for evoking the sense of a higher purpose without invoking gods and superstitions. From the birth of the cosmos to the tragedy of the Ionian civilization to the destruction of the library at Alexandria to today; He manages to place in front of us our own checkered past and at the same time manages to place in front of us our glorious achievements. Take for example this extract from the climactic chapter of this book - "The choice is stark and ironic. The same rocket boosters used to launch probes to the planets are poised to send nuclear warheads to the nations. The radioactive power sources on Viking and Voyager derive from the same technology that makes nuclear weapons."The book ends with a reminder that we have a greater responsibility and a higher loyalty (pun unintended) - "Our obligation to survive is owed not just to ourselves but also to that Cosmos, ancient and vast, from which we spring."Wow.

Quasars. Globular clusters. Black holes. Welcome to the cosmos. I love science even though I find it difficult to discuss and often hard to follow. Sagan does his best to make the planets and movements of our solar system and the universe at large comprehensible and reminds us that we are made of star stuff. He fills our minds with wonder while soaring across the history of stellar human achievement and knowledge. The journey goes from vast expanse of space to our own planet and the miracle of human reproduction, with the end result being a greater appreciation for the world that surrounds us and the struggles we've had just to learn what we know now. Sagan's call to action at the end of the book is as pertinent now as it was in the 1970s: we need to learn to come together and to take care of our planet - because if we don't, who will speak for Earth? In the anti-factual era we find ourselves in, Sagan's voice is dearly missed, but his ideas survive to keep the light of hope and truth alive.

One of the most poetic non-fiction books I’ve read and a manifesto at the same time. It’s curious how Sagan actually tells the story of cosmos as the history of the Earth, of astronomy and of space exploration in order to prove the same point that post-modernist philosophers such as Derrida are trying to make: that of decentralization and deconstruction of authority as a bearer of truth. I’ve always known it, but never understood so vividly that the human knowledge makes it clearer each century - we are not the center of the universe. Such a simple statement, bringing the human race to the next step of development after our narcissistic “terrible three”, and it is definitely not clear yet to most of the world leaders. Apart from this political side, it is just incredibly beautiful, albeit a bit too candid at times, Sagan creating an idea of our galaxy as a home and of the universe as an ocean to explore, not to be afraid of. Although we’ve come to know a lot more about space since 1980, the book seems to have aged really well.

A poignant book with unparalleled breadth of perspective. Countless other reviews already describe it in detail and extoll its virtues, but Cosmos surpassed any expectations I might have had based on high praise lavished on it here and elsewhere. Its masterful synthesis of the history of science and the human race, of cosmos and life on Earth and maybe elsewhere with more recent achievements and insights of our infant species and further with projections into possible futures, grim or splendid as they may be, will stay with me forever. Its admonition against the perils of war made ever more devastating by our growing technical prowess and its voice replete with awe beckoning us to direct our enterprise toward the exploration of our home universe and the stars so that we may survive the adolescence of our species is as relevant now as it was when Sagan first wrote it. Everyone should read this book, period. Put it on your list, make sure you get to it. Put it in your library for your kids to find one day. Now.

4.0 ⭐ “If you wish to make an apple pie from scratch, you must first invent the universe.”   I am young in the act and identity of reading. Even being this young, I’m sure it’s the most important thing of all time, the most important thing I’ve ever done to and for myself, and I’m sure it has more consequence on me than any other experience, person, or event. I am troubled by all the books I’ve yet to read, and I hurry through them as fast as my brain will allow (not very fast, I’m sad to say, but I do try). I'm choosy with nonfiction. I try for things that have made a cultural impact, things I hope will impact me. Cosmos is on a lot of lists like, “Books Everybody Should Read At Least Once”, and “Books To Read Before You Die”, but that’s not why I picked it. I just dig cosmology. I don’t find the subject itself very accessible, I struggle to wrap my head around the seemingly-abstract ideas that might make sense mathematically, but come out as gibberish to me. It’s just that when one of those ideas finally does stick, I see the truth of the subject. Cosmology is one of the few things humanity pursues that admits size. I continuously study history & religion, and everything seems to always be reducing, and compartmentalizing, and shrinking the sum of the world. Cosmology just unleashes that motherfucker inside of your head, and makes no apologies for it. Why should it? Cosmology and its experts didn’t make the universe, after all. They’re just pointing it out. Due to my intellectual limitations, I really need for books like this to be accessible (I’ve been reading A Brief History of Time little by little for months because it takes me so long to understand the concept before I can move on). Cosmos is accessible, but there’s something so cool and so special about it.  Sagan translated the unapologetic size, order, and chaos of his subject, and spun it into poetry. Delicate, human poetry. Sagan, in the space of a few words, takes all that bigness, loneliness, chaos, and even the frustration of not understanding, and points to our ultimate inclusion in all things. As I read Cosmos, I realized I was reading a love letter. If someone must succumb to the vast size of things, how endearing to be led there by a poet. Someone who sees it all, and is truly in love.  I was reminded of Stephen King’s On Writing. King and Sagan sound similar to me because of the love and authority from which they speak. They also have a love for books and education that they speak on seductively. If you think reading is a bore, or don’t think it’s important, just let Stephen or Carl take you to church for a minute. Carl: “Books permit us to voyage through time, to tap the wisdom of our ancestors. The library connects us with the insight and knowledge, painfully extracted from Nature, of the greatest minds that ever were, with the best teachers, drawn from the entire planet and from all our history, to instruct us without tiring, and to inspire us to make our own contribution to the collective knowledge of the human species. I think the health of our civilization, the depth of our awareness about the underpinnings of our culture and our concern for the future can all be tested by how well we support our libraries.” Stephen: “He sat there studiously bent over his work (Bill saw him), which lay in a slant of crisp white winterlight, his face sober and absorbed, knowing that to be a librarian was to come as close as any human being can to sitting in the peak-seat of eternity’s engine.” ( - IT ) And again, in regard to the act of reading words and receiving an image, “ This is what were look­ing at, and we all see it. I didn’t tell you. You didn’t ask me. I never opened my mouth and you never opened yours. We’re not even in the same year together, let alone the same room . . . except we are together. We’re close. We’re having a meeting of the minds.” (- On Writing)  Cosmos, in the same spirit of love, also convicts. There’s a lot our species needs to hold itself accountable for, and it can. In a world where deflecting responsibility or delaying urgent change is common, Cosmos tells hard truths. We can, we just don’t—and why is that? And are we open to self-correction? How long do we want to debate it?  My husband gave a five start review to Stephen King’s On Writing, and he’s not a writer. You don’t have to be into cosmology to love Cosmos. There’s just something all too relatable and beautiful when people speak and you just know, by their spirit and the way they articulate, that they’ve stumbled on to something they can’t keep to themselves. It’s undeniable poetry, and it always leaves me a little dizzy and bubbling over inside my heart. It’s a reverent thing to me. Sagan does this using history, science, humor, and love. And since his subject is life, and all its extensions, your inclusion is inevitable. If you add Cosmos to your library, you’ll catch some of that love yourself. The book deems itself a personal journey, and while that journey was Sagan’s, you may find yourself on your own personal voyage as well. And if that’s not reverent, I don’t know what is. I also watched and enjoyed the 2014 documentary tribute to this book, Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey, and this series deserves praise all across the board, but especially for it’s cosmic calendar break down of the history of planet Earth. And, if you don’t listen to the audio version of Cosmos narrated by the iconic LeVar Burton, you do yourself a disservice.

So, look. When I express my real love and admiration for this book, I’ve had people say to me “Well, you know, the book is out of date.” These people could not have gotten the theme of the book more wrong. (The statement is often accompanied with a condescending chuckle, which doesn’t help things.) Cosmos is about the beauty of science, the opening of our minds to the marvels and glories of the World and Universe around us. It is book that is in every way about the beauty of exploration and the joy and wonder of that journey. And since it’s a journey, to say that some areas of science have moved on from what is discussed/described in the book completely misses the point. Cosmos is about the journey; Sagan is an explorer. Nobody would be happier to find new inroads and ideas in the scientific world than Carl Sagan. Read the book to learn about appreciating the voyage that scientific study takes us on.

Im stuck back on the Wirral at the moment and this has been sitting on the bookshelf in my bedroom for years, so with very little to do and the fact that I'm finding it easier to read non-fiction at the moment I thought now could finally be the time.It's obvious why this book is so beloved, it does everything a popular science book should do. It's easy to follow and doesn't expect any prior knowledge of the subject, but it doesn't talk down or condescend to the reader and is confident enough to tackle difficult subjects.It also has a good mix of scepticism and speculation, it avoids entering into psuedo-science or conspiracy theory territory while still giving a fair hearing to concepts like time travel and aliens that any kid reading the book would be mesmerised by.Maybe if I'd read this back when it was bought for me I would have been inspired to do something useful with my life instead of just reading books, but alas.

This book solicited a review from a really lazy guy like me. It's that good. A must read if you're curious about Life, Universe and Everything!, its cult classic status is no surprise at all. Gives many topics a whole new perspective. And the topics range from history and science to religion and philosophy. In essence - The Cosmos!Reading this book made me once again ponder about many of the unanswered questions I had as a child. Also provides multiple possible answers for those questions. Carl Sagan succeeds in making one think of all the trifles of everyday life (that we put on a pedestal) as silly. Cosmos has definitely had a noticeable impact at least on this little mind of mine.

The awesome book and brilliant propaganda of science. It gives so many ideas, opinions, points of view to think about such as extraterrestrial life, the history of science and so on. Also, this book is so informative because the content covers all existing sciences and even pseudoscience such as astrology. What I liked the most were three things. First, I have learned about the history of astronomy and human development in general; the book gave me a great opportunity to get to know the greatest human-beings who contributed to human progress. Second, it is a beautiful book. Carl Sagan described human discoveries especially in cosmology very well; reading this book was like watching a documentary with all these beautiful pictures of the cosmos. Thirdly, in the end, the author discusses who we (humanity) are and what was our past and what will be our future; Telling what conclusion he made would be a spoiler but I think everyone who is interested in the science should read the last chapter.However, I gave only 4 stars because almost all the materials were familiar to me from the documentaries I watched in National Geographic/ Discovery. So for me, it was like watching a similar documentary. My recommendation is to suggest this book to school students who are just starting their journey in the academics.

This was one hell of a book. I’m so glad I branched out from my usual genres and read it. I cried multiple times, laughed multiple times and thought a whole fucking heap about life, the universe and everything. It was a beautiful and incredibly relevant book—a huge credit to Carl Sagan seeing as it was first pubbed in the eighties. It made me happy and optimistic to be alive and a million other things. I'd recommend it to anyone and it's the best male-written book I’ve read this year.  Space people, get around it.

This book is brilliant. The book covers so many topics and is easy to follow through. From natural selection to black holes, European exploration, ancient civilizations, extraterrestrial life, chemistry, philosophy, linguistics, mercantilism, physics...the list goes on. But, first, this book is about human curiosity and how it can take us far. How a specie born around a peripheral star within a random galaxy called Milky Way and, not even being the physically strongest within your own planet, managed to conquer, to know and build so many things? And how life is possible? Is carbon-based the only way life can exist? There is so much more to question, though.Sagan is a dreamer and a man ahead of his time. And you can easily feel it through his writing. Definitely, one of those people I'd love to spend an afternoon by the sea talking about anything that comes to our minds.(The book is a bit outdated since many discoveries have been made, but still worth.)

There seem to be several reasons why Cosmos remains a classic so many years after its publication. Carl Sagan is a science educator without peer, and his voice lends a sense of both wonder and gravity this book. He incorporates history, philosophy, astrophysics, mathematics, and even ethics and politics in a way that never seems overbearing or obtuse -- instead, these disparate threads are woven together into a grand narrative of mankind's obsession with the universe. Additionally, I listened to Cosmos in its brand new audiobook version, read dramatically by LeVar Burton. His style takes a bit of time to get used to -- he reads with such verve and passion that I'm sure many may find his performance too dramatic -- but a few chapters in I began to really enjoy his enthusiasm. The introductory bits are read by Neil DeGrasse Tyson and Seth MacFarlane, both of whom do an excellent job.

Even before starting the book, I knew that it would get five stars from my side in the review and would turn out to become an all-time favorite.This science classic tells us the wonderful tale of our universe, talks about its beauty, elegance, wonders, unsolved mysteries and awe-inspiring immensity of space-time. If only everyone could read this book, imbibe what Carl wants to convey, human beings would understand a great deal about themselves and others. We will realize how ephemeral our existence is against the backdrop of cosmos and at the same time how precious the life is because of the small probability of the existence of beings like us. Looking from a cosmic perspective, like extra-terrestrials, we would realize how petty our problems are – our issues with another gender, race, religions, nationalities, people having different sets of philosophies and way of living. It will be clear to us how irresponsible our actions are towards the only planet we can call home right now. Reptilian nature of R-complex of our brains has been dominating the cerebral cortex – the seat of our humanity and this has made us the nuclear hostages of the 21st century. We are walking on a thin line, on one side lies self-destruction through nonsense fights amongst each other and another side has the opportunity to achieve the heights, even difficult to imagine, through thoughtful use of science and technology. Every step should be taken with utmost care.Marked by Carl Sagan’s ability to make things interesting to read and easy to absorb, this is a must read for anyone willing to listen to the melody of cosmos and find our place and reason to exist amongst the stars.

Following the light of the sun, Carl Sagan leads us on a Voyage into the farthest expanse of the galaxy back to the smallest component of ourselves. Effortlessly to the beginning of everything into the future. Summarizing seamlessly how each generation sits like dwarfs on the shoulder of past giants reaching further than ever before. His book is awesome in the awe-inspiring way it used to mean. The way Sagan ties everything together in such simplicity leaves me with a feeling of pure joy. I don't think I can look at the night sky the same way after reading this book.

Though it shows its age in some specific respects, due to thirty years of scientific discovery since its publication (this book came before we understood the nature of quasars, before the confirmation of quarks and other elementary particles in the Standard Model, and before we realized we are situated in the Virgo Supercluster of galaxies, among other things), Cosmos still astonishes with its poignant blend of scientific inquiry and philosophical musing. If its only objective is to broaden one's perspective from one's immediate surroundings to the grandiosity of the cosmos itself, then it succeeds. It is an exploration of our history as always learning, curious creatures—our successes as well as our failures. Many pages are also devoted to imagining what possible future lays before us. Shall we learn to travel close to the speed of light, colonizing planets in systems light-years from our own? Or will we destroy ourselves first, as perhaps many other intelligent species have before us (this may be why the galaxy seems so... quiet), either with nuclear weapons (Sagan's key concern), or with the more timely spectre of climate change (something that this book slightly predates). In its final pages, Sagan pleas for peace. Humanity ought not destroy itself over ultimately petty differences, but rather share a common purpose as a species: to explore and learn as much as we can about our ancient and beautiful home, the cosmos. It's interesting reading such a thing in the era of Trump, where such unification of humanity seems impossible. But given enough time, and resisting the worst of our destructive and apathetic impulses, Sagan's plea seems possible. Having just finished the book, I'm left slightly more optimistic for our little species.

4.5 Stars....Last weekend I was in the desert in the middle east where I had the opportunity to sleep under the stars...I downloaded a really cool app on my phone that shows all the constellations where ever you point your phone....I just happened to be lying right under the constellation of Cygnus... Or the swan....Well wasn't it a surprise that the very next day as I was reading this book, Sagan described this very same constellation among others in our galaxy...This book by Sagan is a wonderful look into our universe and into ourselves.... We are all made up of star dust... And what makes up stars more than the light that they gives off....I read somewhere that the western approach to Einstein's Theory of Relativity involves a observer and that which he is observing... And in between the two they are both separated by time...That the speed of light is 'relative' due to the distance that the observer is away from the light he is observing... Hence the relativity.... For instance the sun could've have blown up 8 minutes ago since it takes 8 minutes for the light from the sun to reach us... or... As i noticed lying under the stars last weekend that as soon as the sun comes up, the stars in the sky disappear.... The stars are still there but are hidden from the light emerging from the sun... It's all relative...The eastern approach however, is that to truly study the speed of light we must sit on the light... We must move with the light... This is where the observer and the observed become one... And when the two become one there is no time separating them... This is when we begin to move with light....If we are made up of stardust, why can we not emit light like the stars?Sagan writes, "The Hindu religion is the only one of the world's great faiths dedicated to the idea that the Cosmos itself undergoes an immense, indeed an infinite, number of deaths and rebirths. it is the only religion in which the time scales correspond, no doubt by accident, to those of modern scientific cosmology."This book is like a door that opens up the expanse of imagination... it's like finding our way outside a room... And sparking a curiosity towards our universe...

Cosmos should be a required reading at school. Very informative book touching on wide range of science departments. You will be informed about DNA and heredity, chemistry and of course astrophysics. You will get a history lesson as well. The book covers everything from history of Earth to the time of Sagan. It discusses its possible futures, both splended and omnious. It educates you, warns you, but most importantly ... it inspires you.

This audiobook needs your undivided attention or you will miss something and be utterly confused. I'm not sure how much I actually retained but it was a fascinating book! There was a LOT of information! I had no idea the Milky Way was named after breast milk! *the more you know* Narrated by LeVar Burton of my Reading Rainbow childhood, huzzah!! With cameos from Neil deGrasse Tyson, Seth McFarlane, and Sagan's widow and partner in science crime, Ann Druyan.

Enjoyed this very much. I am fascinated by the stars, and space and so really enjoyed a book that went to so much trouble to make the science accessible. From the great library of Alexandria to nucluer holocaust, Sagan had a wonderful way of making hard concepts vivid, and relevant. Written what, 30 years ago now? it can feel dated at times .. but the ideas are extraordinary. And there is a wealth of information I will bring with me to every starry conversation I have from here on out.

Absolutely wonderful. Marvelous. Easily 5 stars. No. Easily a galaxy's worth of stars.This is Sagan's most influential work. The book/TV series was responsible for influencing generations of scientists. He elegantly explains the workings of our universe, from the molecules living in the subatomic world to the commodious galaxies and everything in between. An absolute joy to read. Carl Sagan is my hero.

This book has bit of everything from history, politics, culture, and science. They all converge to one goal: higher state of humanity. Comprehending this book is not easy, but once you do, you will imagine many things about unthinkable possibilities. This book is for mankind's best destiny, after we finished tearing down each other.

Must read for EVERYONE. Whether you like it or not, science is something you must know. Carl Sagan narrates the cosmos story with words that will take you back and forth the spacetime. Some points and themes may seem repeated throughout the book, but it's like repeatedly striking a nail with hammer to "nail" the point. It's a book everybody should read and think about.

I rarely write reviews, but this book was so mind-blowing and elegant that I couldn't not. It's so much broader than a science book, and definitely more than a space book, it explains everything from atoms to the universe, and is written in in beautiful, compelling prose. I might have to buy this for everyone I know at Christmas.

my god... really, how do i even start talking about this book? that i want carl sagan to be my uncle? that i finally found a "science"-y person who also appreciates the wonder of the universe, world, & humanity so intensely that i feel it in my chest? that the soliloquy in the backbone of night made me want to cry because of how beautiful it is? i don't know. this book just affirms me even more that i have to be the person who still believes in the interconnection of the humanities/arts & the sciences, because as carl sagan so eloquently puts it in here, they're all part of humanity. the choice is clearly the universe or nothing. cosmos both humbled & uplifted me. i can't thank it enough.

We are all made of starstuff.It has been a while since a book made me really reflect on how small and insignificant our lives and our place in the universe is. It has been a while since I got existential dread. It has been a while since I pondered my mortality.Thanks Carl Sagan for being a passionate voice of logic and reason in our dark and troubled times. You left too soon.

This was my first book by Sagan despite him being one of my childhood heroes, mainly due to the original Cosmos show and a few excerpts from his writings (the Pale Blue Dot passage, for example).Put simply, this book inspired me, and I don’t think I can honestly say that any other book has ever done so. Entertained, yes. Enlightened, of course. But never inspired. After three decades, I thought I was just the uninspired type. A book about science made me emotional. It made me think about humanity as a whole, about our amazing yet fragile progress on the long timeline of the universe, about our future. And more importantly, about my personal part in that future. Times are dark and we are seemingly more divided than we’ve been in many decades. Yet from where he sat only a few years ago, Carl Sagan had advice for us. He seemed to see the intrinsic problems facing us as a species, the flaws that might lead to our ultimate destruction, yes. But also—ever the inspiration—he saw a way forward. And maybe unsurprisingly, that way forward is simple and heartfelt. Simple, but perhaps not easy. There was so much in this book that hit home for me, or fascinated me, or gave me a sense of a kind of cosmic vertigo (in the best possible way). I found myself rereading passages on biology, chemistry, and physics in order to ensure I understood, out of a genuine interest in those subjects as presented by Sagan. With very few exceptions, interest in science hasn’t been my nature. I thought maybe I just didn’t have the brain for it. Turns out I didn’t have the right teacher. This kind of communication of science, this kind of inspiration... we need it more than ever. No one living now seems to be coming close, at least not anyone doing it on a large scale in popular media. I wish we still had someone like him, and like my little obsession with Joseph Campbell, I’m sure I’ll be reading a lot more of Sagan’s work.

Given the stunning eloquence with which Sagan writes Cosmos, I wish I were able to express my thoughts on the book in a more articulate way. Sadly, my writing caliber is not up to the challenge yet, so I’ll just start with “I loved this book.” Even though Sagan built his career in astronomy, he shows such respect towards all areas of knowledge, including the history --some of my favorite passages are ones where he discusses different stories of scientific discovery (never knew that Kepler and Tycho Brahe had such a troubled working relationship) or looks to the past for guidance on what to expect in the future (such as when he pointed to the meeting of Europeans and indigenous peoples in the Americas as a potential case study for future extraterrestrial contact). While all the material in the book was fascinating, one of my favorite chapters was “Blues for a Red Planet,” which chronicles the exploration of Mars by the Viking missions, as well as the challenges faced in the years of preparation leading up to launch. Even though the information related is several decades old, it deepened my respect for the ingenuity and expertise that went into the program and reminded me just how incredible it is that we’ve landed machines that were able to conduct experiments on the dirt of a planet hundreds of millions of miles away. I’m sure Sagan would be overjoyed to learn about the progress made on Mars rovers in the years since. Cosmos is absolutely wonderful in every sense and I’m sure it will continue to inspire curiosity in scientific endeavors and an appreciation for our place in the universe for many future generations of readers.

Personal ReviewI thought that this was a very good book. It was very informative. The author talked about astronomy through history and many of the big discoveries and how they changed through the years. The author made learning very fun for the common person. I thought that every chapter had something unique to offer and learn about.SummaryAt the beginning of each chapter the author starts it off with a historical quote dealing with that specific chapter. There is an introduction that gives an overview of the entire book and a very philosophical perspective on the subject. The author talks about some of the theories we have today and how they were influenced by discoveries thousands of years ago. He also explains the culture and government of the people that made these great discoveries. After this, the author shifts to talking about some of the modern day adventures of human space craft and how we are soon to visit other worlds. He talks about how science is sort of a religion and how it has changed the way the human race has thought over our thousands of years as a species. The author sort of goes back and forth to ancient and common times throughout the rest of the book.RecommendationI think that any scientist or anybody interested in physics would love this book. Just the fact that it is written by one of the most famous scientists of our time, Carl Sagan, is very appealing in itself. I also think that a high school physics student would be very well off if they read this book. The author does a very good job of explaining many very complex principles at the most elementary level possible.

I am genuinely upset that this isn't required reading for all 8th graders.I should've been offered this book! It should be free!I think we would have an even greater appreciation of science in society if this were more widely read. It's a fascinating look at the history of science and the development of ideas. What's more, Carl Sagan is a beautiful person, and it's very intimate to hear his childhood outlook and what sparked his curiosity. The speculations of how past events have turned out can be disheartening. Dr. Sagan defends the complexities of whale communication; how they can communicate thousands of kilometers apart, essentially having evolved a natural telephone system they've relied upon for centuries. He laments the disruptions human navies have caused by our wanton use of sonar and radio communications to the extent that whales are limited to communication of a few kilometers. There is also the then unknown effects of climate change and the recognition of the small progress we've had today.I thought this book would be far outdated, but I now believe it is timeless. Also, if Levar Burton had read all my textbooks to me, I would've had multiple PhD's in science by now.

This made my head asplode. "On another planet, with a different sequence of random processes to make hereditary diversity and a different environment to select particular combinations of genes, the chances of finding beings who are physically very similar to us is, I believe, near zero. The chances of finding another form of intelligence is not. Their brains may well have evolved from the inside out. They may have switching elements analogous to our neurons. But the neurons may be very different; perhaps superconductors that work at very low temperatures rather than organic devices that work at room temperature, in which case their speed of thought will be 10*7 times faster than ours. Or perhaps the equivalent of neurons elsewhere would not be in direct physical contact but in radio communication so that a single intelligent being could be distributed among many different organisms, or even many different planets, each with a part of the intelligence of the whole, each contributing by radio to an intelligence much greater than itself"

What a fascinating book! And so eloquently written. Carl Sagan has a knack for evoking the sense of a higher purpose without invoking gods and superstitions. From the birth of the cosmos to the tragedy of the Ionian civilization to the destruction of the library at Alexandria to today; He manages to place in front of us our own checkered past and at the same time manages to place in front of us our glorious achievements. Take for example this extract from the climactic chapter of this book - "The choice is stark and ironic. The same rocket boosters used to launch probes to the planets are poised to send nuclear warheads to the nations. The radioactive power sources on Viking and Voyager derive from the same technology that makes nuclear weapons."The book ends with a reminder that we have a greater responsibility and a higher loyalty (pun unintended) - "Our obligation to survive is owed not just to ourselves but also to that Cosmos, ancient and vast, from which we spring."Wow.

Quasars. Globular clusters. Black holes. Welcome to the cosmos. I love science even though I find it difficult to discuss and often hard to follow. Sagan does his best to make the planets and movements of our solar system and the universe at large comprehensible and reminds us that we are made of star stuff. He fills our minds with wonder while soaring across the history of stellar human achievement and knowledge. The journey goes from vast expanse of space to our own planet and the miracle of human reproduction, with the end result being a greater appreciation for the world that surrounds us and the struggles we've had just to learn what we know now. Sagan's call to action at the end of the book is as pertinent now as it was in the 1970s: we need to learn to come together and to take care of our planet - because if we don't, who will speak for Earth? In the anti-factual era we find ourselves in, Sagan's voice is dearly missed, but his ideas survive to keep the light of hope and truth alive.

One of the most poetic non-fiction books I’ve read and a manifesto at the same time. It’s curious how Sagan actually tells the story of cosmos as the history of the Earth, of astronomy and of space exploration in order to prove the same point that post-modernist philosophers such as Derrida are trying to make: that of decentralization and deconstruction of authority as a bearer of truth. I’ve always known it, but never understood so vividly that the human knowledge makes it clearer each century - we are not the center of the universe. Such a simple statement, bringing the human race to the next step of development after our narcissistic “terrible three”, and it is definitely not clear yet to most of the world leaders. Apart from this political side, it is just incredibly beautiful, albeit a bit too candid at times, Sagan creating an idea of our galaxy as a home and of the universe as an ocean to explore, not to be afraid of. Although we’ve come to know a lot more about space since 1980, the book seems to have aged really well.

A poignant book with unparalleled breadth of perspective. Countless other reviews already describe it in detail and extoll its virtues, but Cosmos surpassed any expectations I might have had based on high praise lavished on it here and elsewhere. Its masterful synthesis of the history of science and the human race, of cosmos and life on Earth and maybe elsewhere with more recent achievements and insights of our infant species and further with projections into possible futures, grim or splendid as they may be, will stay with me forever. Its admonition against the perils of war made ever more devastating by our growing technical prowess and its voice replete with awe beckoning us to direct our enterprise toward the exploration of our home universe and the stars so that we may survive the adolescence of our species is as relevant now as it was when Sagan first wrote it. Everyone should read this book, period. Put it on your list, make sure you get to it. Put it in your library for your kids to find one day. Now.

4.0 ⭐ “If you wish to make an apple pie from scratch, you must first invent the universe.”   I am young in the act and identity of reading. Even being this young, I’m sure it’s the most important thing of all time, the most important thing I’ve ever done to and for myself, and I’m sure it has more consequence on me than any other experience, person, or event. I am troubled by all the books I’ve yet to read, and I hurry through them as fast as my brain will allow (not very fast, I’m sad to say, but I do try). I'm choosy with nonfiction. I try for things that have made a cultural impact, things I hope will impact me. Cosmos is on a lot of lists like, “Books Everybody Should Read At Least Once”, and “Books To Read Before You Die”, but that’s not why I picked it. I just dig cosmology. I don’t find the subject itself very accessible, I struggle to wrap my head around the seemingly-abstract ideas that might make sense mathematically, but come out as gibberish to me. It’s just that when one of those ideas finally does stick, I see the truth of the subject. Cosmology is one of the few things humanity pursues that admits size. I continuously study history & religion, and everything seems to always be reducing, and compartmentalizing, and shrinking the sum of the world. Cosmology just unleashes that motherfucker inside of your head, and makes no apologies for it. Why should it? Cosmology and its experts didn’t make the universe, after all. They’re just pointing it out. Due to my intellectual limitations, I really need for books like this to be accessible (I’ve been reading A Brief History of Time little by little for months because it takes me so long to understand the concept before I can move on). Cosmos is accessible, but there’s something so cool and so special about it.  Sagan translated the unapologetic size, order, and chaos of his subject, and spun it into poetry. Delicate, human poetry. Sagan, in the space of a few words, takes all that bigness, loneliness, chaos, and even the frustration of not understanding, and points to our ultimate inclusion in all things. As I read Cosmos, I realized I was reading a love letter. If someone must succumb to the vast size of things, how endearing to be led there by a poet. Someone who sees it all, and is truly in love.  I was reminded of Stephen King’s On Writing. King and Sagan sound similar to me because of the love and authority from which they speak. They also have a love for books and education that they speak on seductively. If you think reading is a bore, or don’t think it’s important, just let Stephen or Carl take you to church for a minute. Carl: “Books permit us to voyage through time, to tap the wisdom of our ancestors. The library connects us with the insight and knowledge, painfully extracted from Nature, of the greatest minds that ever were, with the best teachers, drawn from the entire planet and from all our history, to instruct us without tiring, and to inspire us to make our own contribution to the collective knowledge of the human species. I think the health of our civilization, the depth of our awareness about the underpinnings of our culture and our concern for the future can all be tested by how well we support our libraries.” Stephen: “He sat there studiously bent over his work (Bill saw him), which lay in a slant of crisp white winterlight, his face sober and absorbed, knowing that to be a librarian was to come as close as any human being can to sitting in the peak-seat of eternity’s engine.” ( - IT ) And again, in regard to the act of reading words and receiving an image, “ This is what were look­ing at, and we all see it. I didn’t tell you. You didn’t ask me. I never opened my mouth and you never opened yours. We’re not even in the same year together, let alone the same room . . . except we are together. We’re close. We’re having a meeting of the minds.” (- On Writing)  Cosmos, in the same spirit of love, also convicts. There’s a lot our species needs to hold itself accountable for, and it can. In a world where deflecting responsibility or delaying urgent change is common, Cosmos tells hard truths. We can, we just don’t—and why is that? And are we open to self-correction? How long do we want to debate it?  My husband gave a five start review to Stephen King’s On Writing, and he’s not a writer. You don’t have to be into cosmology to love Cosmos. There’s just something all too relatable and beautiful when people speak and you just know, by their spirit and the way they articulate, that they’ve stumbled on to something they can’t keep to themselves. It’s undeniable poetry, and it always leaves me a little dizzy and bubbling over inside my heart. It’s a reverent thing to me. Sagan does this using history, science, humor, and love. And since his subject is life, and all its extensions, your inclusion is inevitable. If you add Cosmos to your library, you’ll catch some of that love yourself. The book deems itself a personal journey, and while that journey was Sagan’s, you may find yourself on your own personal voyage as well. And if that’s not reverent, I don’t know what is. I also watched and enjoyed the 2014 documentary tribute to this book, Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey, and this series deserves praise all across the board, but especially for it’s cosmic calendar break down of the history of planet Earth. And, if you don’t listen to the audio version of Cosmos narrated by the iconic LeVar Burton, you do yourself a disservice.

So, look. When I express my real love and admiration for this book, I’ve had people say to me “Well, you know, the book is out of date.” These people could not have gotten the theme of the book more wrong. (The statement is often accompanied with a condescending chuckle, which doesn’t help things.) Cosmos is about the beauty of science, the opening of our minds to the marvels and glories of the World and Universe around us. It is book that is in every way about the beauty of exploration and the joy and wonder of that journey. And since it’s a journey, to say that some areas of science have moved on from what is discussed/described in the book completely misses the point. Cosmos is about the journey; Sagan is an explorer. Nobody would be happier to find new inroads and ideas in the scientific world than Carl Sagan. Read the book to learn about appreciating the voyage that scientific study takes us on.

Im stuck back on the Wirral at the moment and this has been sitting on the bookshelf in my bedroom for years, so with very little to do and the fact that I'm finding it easier to read non-fiction at the moment I thought now could finally be the time.It's obvious why this book is so beloved, it does everything a popular science book should do. It's easy to follow and doesn't expect any prior knowledge of the subject, but it doesn't talk down or condescend to the reader and is confident enough to tackle difficult subjects.It also has a good mix of scepticism and speculation, it avoids entering into psuedo-science or conspiracy theory territory while still giving a fair hearing to concepts like time travel and aliens that any kid reading the book would be mesmerised by.Maybe if I'd read this back when it was bought for me I would have been inspired to do something useful with my life instead of just reading books, but alas.

How a specie born around a peripheral star within a random galaxy called Milky Way and, not even being the physically strongest within your own planet, managed to conquer, to know and build so many things? There seem to be several reasons why Cosmos remains a classic so many years after its publication. Carl Sagan is a science educator without peer, and his voice lends a sense of both wonder and gravity this book. He incorporates history, philosophy, astrophysics, mathematics, and even ethics and politics in a way that never seems overbearing or obtuse -- instead, these disparate threads are woven together into a grand narrative of mankind's obsession with the universe. Additionally, I listened to Cosmos in its brand new audiobook version, read dramatically by LeVar Burton. His style takes a bit of time to get used to -- he reads with such verve and passion that I'm sure many may find his performance too dramatic -- but a few chapters in I began to really enjoy his enthusiasm. The introductory bits are read by Neil DeGrasse Tyson and Seth MacFarlane, both of whom do an excellent job.

Even before starting the book, I knew that it would get five stars from my side in the review and would turn out to become an all-time favorite.This science classic tells us the wonderful tale of our universe, talks about its beauty, elegance, wonders, unsolved mysteries and awe-inspiring immensity of space-time. If only everyone could read this book, imbibe what Carl wants to convey, human beings would understand a great deal about themselves and others. We will realize how ephemeral our existence is against the backdrop of cosmos and at the same time how precious the life is because of the small probability of the existence of beings like us. Looking from a cosmic perspective, like extra-terrestrials, we would realize how petty our problems are – our issues with another gender, race, religions, nationalities, people having different sets of philosophies and way of living. It will be clear to us how irresponsible our actions are towards the only planet we can call home right now. Reptilian nature of R-complex of our brains has been dominating the cerebral cortex – the seat of our humanity and this has made us the nuclear hostages of the 21st century. We are walking on a thin line, on one side lies self-destruction through nonsense fights amongst each other and another side has the opportunity to achieve the heights, even difficult to imagine, through thoughtful use of science and technology. Every step should be taken with utmost care.Marked by Carl Sagan’s ability to make things interesting to read and easy to absorb, this is a must read for anyone willing to listen to the melody of cosmos and find our place and reason to exist amongst the stars.

Following the light of the sun, Carl Sagan leads us on a Voyage into the farthest expanse of the galaxy back to the smallest component of ourselves. Effortlessly to the beginning of everything into the future. Summarizing seamlessly how each generation sits like dwarfs on the shoulder of past giants reaching further than ever before. His book is awesome in the awe-inspiring way it used to mean. The way Sagan ties everything together in such simplicity leaves me with a feeling of pure joy. I don't think I can look at the night sky the same way after reading this book.

Though it shows its age in some specific respects, due to thirty years of scientific discovery since its publication (this book came before we understood the nature of quasars, before the confirmation of quarks and other elementary particles in the Standard Model, and before we realized we are situated in the Virgo Supercluster of galaxies, among other things), Cosmos still astonishes with its poignant blend of scientific inquiry and philosophical musing. If its only objective is to broaden one's perspective from one's immediate surroundings to the grandiosity of the cosmos itself, then it succeeds. It is an exploration of our history as always learning, curious creatures—our successes as well as our failures. Many pages are also devoted to imagining what possible future lays before us. Shall we learn to travel close to the speed of light, colonizing planets in systems light-years from our own? Or will we destroy ourselves first, as perhaps many other intelligent species have before us (this may be why the galaxy seems so... quiet), either with nuclear weapons (Sagan's key concern), or with the more timely spectre of climate change (something that this book slightly predates). In its final pages, Sagan pleas for peace. Humanity ought not destroy itself over ultimately petty differences, but rather share a common purpose as a species: to explore and learn as much as we can about our ancient and beautiful home, the cosmos. It's interesting reading such a thing in the era of Trump, where such unification of humanity seems impossible. But given enough time, and resisting the worst of our destructive and apathetic impulses, Sagan's plea seems possible. Having just finished the book, I'm left slightly more optimistic for our little species.

4.5 Stars....Last weekend I was in the desert in the middle east where I had the opportunity to sleep under the stars...I downloaded a really cool app on my phone that shows all the constellations where ever you point your phone....I just happened to be lying right under the constellation of Cygnus... Or the swan....Well wasn't it a surprise that the very next day as I was reading this book, Sagan described this very same constellation among others in our galaxy...This book by Sagan is a wonderful look into our universe and into ourselves.... We are all made up of star dust... And what makes up stars more than the light that they gives off....I read somewhere that the western approach to Einstein's Theory of Relativity involves a observer and that which he is observing... And in between the two they are both separated by time...That the speed of light is 'relative' due to the distance that the observer is away from the light he is observing... Hence the relativity.... For instance the sun could've have blown up 8 minutes ago since it takes 8 minutes for the light from the sun to reach us... or... As i noticed lying under the stars last weekend that as soon as the sun comes up, the stars in the sky disappear.... The stars are still there but are hidden from the light emerging from the sun... It's all relative...The eastern approach however, is that to truly study the speed of light we must sit on the light... We must move with the light... This is where the observer and the observed become one... And when the two become one there is no time separating them... This is when we begin to move with light....If we are made up of stardust, why can we not emit light like the stars?Sagan writes, "The Hindu religion is the only one of the world's great faiths dedicated to the idea that the Cosmos itself undergoes an immense, indeed an infinite, number of deaths and rebirths. it is the only religion in which the time scales correspond, no doubt by accident, to those of modern scientific cosmology."This book is like a door that opens up the expanse of imagination... it's like finding our way outside a room... And sparking a curiosity towards our universe...

Carl Sagan was my hero when I was a teenager. This book had a huge influence on me then. I still think it is a great book. I just don't see nuclear war as an absolute inevitability. Interesting though was the idea that as the population increases the scientific progress decreases. Neil DeGrasse Tyson WISHES.Man, Carl Sagan was the bomb. Cosmos is an endlessly engaging beginner's guide to understanding the universe that's impossible to put down even if you've learned most of this stuff before. Sagan's writing is terrifically clear, evocative, and entertaining, and his wit, passion, and boundless optimism shines on every page.
